title: White v. J. M. Brown Amusement Co.
description: The Court held that a contract became void and unenforceable when the subject matter of the contract--video poker machines--became illegal.  In addition, the Court held that the contract was not revived when the local option law, which allowed residents to vote on the legality of video poker machines, was held unconstitutional.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Supreme Court

 
   
     
      
        Phillip W. White, individually, and Little General Food Stores, Inc., 
          Petitioners,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        J.M. Brown Amusement Co., Inc., Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal from Anderson County
  Â James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25849
  Heard June 22, 2004 - Filed August 9, 2004

REVERSED

 
   
     
      
        Daniel L. Draisen, Krause & Moorhead, PA, of Anderson, for Petitioners.
        Amy G. Richmond, of Love, Thornton, Arnold & Thomason, V. Clark 
          Price, and Dana M. Lahey, both of Roe Cassidy Coates & Price, PA, 
          all of Greenville, and Wade S. Weatherford, III, of Gaffney, for Respondent.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  The court of appeals 
  reversed the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment to Phillip W. White and 
  Little General Food Stores, Inc. (collectively â€œWhiteâ€).Â  White v. J.M. Brown 
  Amusement Co., Op. No. 2003-UP-161 (S.C. Ct. App. filed February 27, 2003).Â  
  We granted Whiteâ€™s petition for a writ of certiorari to review that decision 
  and now reverse.
FACTUAL / PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In 1992, White and J.M. Brown Amusement Co. (â€œBrownâ€) entered into a contract 
  giving Brown exclusive rights to place â€œcertain coin-operated amusement machinesâ€ 
  in thirteen of Whiteâ€™s storesâ€”which Brown didâ€”all located in Anderson and Oconee 
  counties.Â  The contract was for a term of fifteen years.Â  Under the contract, 
  White agreed â€œnot to allow other machines on the premises without the express 
  written consent of [Brown].â€ 
In 1993, the Legislature enacted a local option law as part of the Video Game 
  Machines Act, permitting counties to hold an individual referendum to determine 
  whether cash payouts for video gaming should remain legal.Â  Act No. 164, Part 
  II, Â§ 19G, 1993 S.C. Acts 1138-1139, formerly codified at S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 
  12-21-2806 and -2808 (repealed effective July 1, 2000).Â  As a result of local 
  referenda held in November 1994, twelve counties, including Oconee and Anderson, 
  voted to ban cash payouts.Â  The South Carolina Department of Revenue revoked 
  the licenses required to operate the machines Brown had placed in Whiteâ€™s stores, 
  effective July 1, 1995, as required by the Act.Â  Consequently, Brown removed 
  the video poker machines from Whiteâ€™s stores.Â  Brown did not replace the machines 
  with any other coin-operated amusement machines.
In November 1996, this Court struck down the local option law contained in 
  the Act as unconstitutional special legislation.Â  Martin v. Condon, 324 
  S.C. 183, 478 S.E.2d 272 (1996).Â  Given this Courtâ€™s ruling, Brown planned to 
  return the video poker machines to Whiteâ€™s store, but White informed Brown that 
  the contract was no longer valid.Â  White then initiated the underlying action, 
  seeking to have the contract declared void and unenforceable so that he would 
  be free to sign a contract with another provider of legal video and amusement 
  machines. White also alleged that Brown breached the contract by removing the 
  machines from Whiteâ€™s stores and failing to replace them with appropriate machines. 

Approximately one month after filing suit, White entered into an agreement 
  with Hughes Entertainment, Inc. (â€œHughesâ€), giving Hughes exclusive rights to 
  place â€œall video game terminals and all coin operated music and amusement machinesâ€ 
  in twelve of the same stores listed in the Brown contract.
 In its answer to the complaint, Brown denied breaching the contract, arguing 
  that the machines were removed from Whiteâ€™s stores â€œin response to Court and 
  legislative proceedings which cast doubt upon the legality of certain coin operated 
  machines such as those supplied by [Brown] to [White] under the terms of the 
  contract.â€Â  In addition, Brown asserted counterclaims for breach of contract 
  and breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act because White contracted 
  with Hughes for placement of machines in Whiteâ€™s stores.
A representative of Brown testified in deposition that the subject matter of 
  the contract was the outlawed video poker machinesâ€”the only type of machines 
  Brown handled.Â  White testified in deposition that he expected Brown to install 
  other types of legal video games after the video poker machines were outlawed, 
  even though White also testified that the contract involved video poker machines, 
  and he never asked Brown (from July 1995 to November 1996) to place other types 
  of machines in his stores.
White moved for summary judgment on Brownâ€™s counterclaims.Â  The trial court 
  granted Whiteâ€™s motion, finding that the contract involved the placement and 
  operation of outlawed video poker machines. 
  [1] Â  The trial court concluded that as a matter of law, the contract between 
  White and Brown â€œbecame void and unenforceable as of July 1, 1995, when video 
  poker machines first became illegal in Anderson and Oconee counties.â€Â  The trial 
  court subsequently denied Brownâ€™s motion to reconsider.
Brown appealed and the court of appeals reversed.Â  The court of appeals reasoned 
  that because this Court had struck down the local option law and referenda as 
  unconstitutional, the validity of the contract must be analyzed as if the local 
  option law had never been enacted, the referenda never held, the county ordinances 
  banning video poker payouts never passed, and the machine licenses never revoked 
  by the Department of Revenue.
We granted certiorari to resolve the following question: 
  [2] 

  Did the court of appeals err in reversing the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary 
    judgment to White, where the trial court found that the contract was void 
    and unenforceable as of July 1, 1995, due to local referenda banning the type 
    of video poker machine that formed the subject matter of the contract?Â  

LAW/ ANALYSIS
Standard of Review
When reviewing the grant of summary judgment, the 
  appellate court applies the same standard applied by the trial court pursuant 
  to Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493, 567 S.E.2d 
  857, 860 (2002). Summary judgment is appropriate when there is no genuine issue 
  of material fact such that the moving party must prevail as a matter of law.Â  
  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Tupper v. Dorchester County, 326 S.C. 318, 325, 487 
  S.E.2d 187, 191 (1997).Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, 
  the court must view the evidence and all reasonable inferences that may be drawn 
  from the evidence in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Manning 
  v. Quinn, 294 S.C. 383, 385, 365 S.E.2d 24, 25 (1988).
Discussion
White asserts the court of appeals erred because the trial court correctly 
  held that as a matter of law, the partiesâ€™ contract became void and unenforceable 
  as of July 1, 1995, the date it became illegal to operate the video poker machines.Â  
  White also contends that the contract was not revived when the local option 
  law was held unconstitutional.Â  We agree.
The general rule, well established in South Carolina, is that courts will not 
  enforce a contract when the subject matter of the contract or an act required 
  for performance violates public policy as expressed in constitutional provisions, 
  statutory law, or judicial decisions.Â  Berkebile v. Outen, 311 S.C. 50, 
  53-54, 426 S.E.2d 760, 762 (1993) (stating â€œ[a]n illegal contract has always 
  been unenforceableâ€); Batchelor v. American Health Ins. Co., 234 S.C. 
  103, 107 S.E.2d 36 (1959) (noting that contracts violating public policy as 
  expressed in constitutional provisions, statutes, or judicial decisions are 
  void).
When a contract is originally legal, but performance becomes illegal due to 
  a change in the law, any subsequent performance is against public policy and 
  the party who has agreed to perform is excused from doing so. Â Some courts analyze 
  such a situation in terms of impossibility of performance, although performance 
  is not literally â€œimpossibleâ€ because it could be done if it were legal.Â  Other 
  courts simply conclude that the duty to perform is excused or discharged because 
  performance would violate public policy as expressed in constitutional provisions, 
  statutes, or judicial decisions.Â  8 Williston on Contracts Â§ 19:35 (4th 
  ed. 1998); 14 Corbin on Contracts Â§ 76.1 (2001); see also Restatement 
  (Second) of Contracts Â§ 264 (1981) (â€œif the performance of a duty is made 
  impracticable by having to comply with a domestic or foreign governmental regulation 
  or order, that regulation or order is an event the non-occurrence of which was 
  a basic assumption on which the contract was madeâ€); Restatement (First) 
  of Contracts Â§ 458 (1932) (contractual duty is discharged where performance 
  is subsequently prevented or prohibited by constitutional provision, statute, 
  ordinance, judicial decision, or administrative order); Annot., Modern Status 
  of the Rules Regarding Impossibility of Performance as Defense in Action for 
  Breach of Contract, 84 A.L.R.2d 12, Â§ 7 (1962).
In the present case, both parties were performing as required under the contract 
  until performance of the contract became legally impossible for two reasons.Â  
  First, the subject matter of the contractâ€”certain video poker machinesâ€”became 
  illegal as of July 1, 1995, under the local option law and the resulting local 
  referenda.Â  Second, as mandated by the local option law, the Department of Revenue 
  revoked the licenses required to legally possess and use the machines.Â  Consequently, 
  both partiesâ€™ duty to perform under the contract was discharged, and after that 
  point, White and Brown were free to enter a new contract involving legal machines 
  or seek other contractual relationships.Â  
Moreover, because the subject matter of the contract 
  became illegal, the contract itself was invalidated or rendered â€œdead.â€Â  Therefore, 
  the next issue we must address is whether the â€œdeadâ€ contract was revived when 
  this Court deemed the local option lawâ€”which permitted counties to hold an individual 
  referendum to determine whether cash payouts for video gaming should remain 
  legalâ€”unconstitutional.
The court of appeals implicitly concluded that 
  the formerly â€œdeadâ€ contract was indeed revived by the â€œdeathâ€ of the invalid 
  law, when the court stated â€œ[i]t is as if the law had never been passed and 
  the referenda never held.â€Â  In support of its conclusion, the court of appeals 
  relied solely on Atkinson v. Southern Express Co., 94 S.C. 444, 78 S.E. 
  516 (1913).Â  In that case, the Court stated the following:Â  

  When a statute is adjudged to be unconstitutional, it is as if it never had 
    been.Â  Rights cannot be built up under it; contracts which depend upon it 
    for their consideration are void; it constitutes a protection to no one who 
    has acted under it; and no one can be punished for having refused obedience 
    to it before the decision was made.Â  

Id. at 453, 78 S.E. at 519 (citations and 
  internal quotation marks omitted).Â  Based on this precedent, the court of appeals 
  concluded that â€œthe ordinance purporting to ban the video poker machines had 
  no legal forceâ€ and therefore did not have a legal effect on the partiesâ€™ contract.Â  

Given the court of appealsâ€™ decision, Brown asserts that the invalidation of 
  the local option law somehow revived the dead contract for the remainder of 
  its fifteen-year term.Â  Brown essentially is asking us to reshape the course 
  of events and impact those events had on the partiesâ€™ contractual relationship 
  by pretending that the unconstitutional statute and the local referenda never 
  existed.
We reject Brownâ€™s argument and hold the contract was not revived by the subsequent 
  invalidation of the local option law.Â  This holding allows parties to conduct 
  business and plan their affairs with some degree of certainty.Â  Life goes on 
  while judicial or legislative processes run their course.Â  In the meantime, 
  parties must arrange and conduct their business affairs under the law as it 
  presently exists, regardless of a belief or hope the law will later be changed 
  or invalidated.
 We find this result to be consistent with precedent, including the recently 
  decided case of Bergstrom v. Palmetto Health Alliance, 358 S.C. 388, 
  596 S.E.2d 42 (2004).Â  In Bergstrom, we held that a 1977 statute, which 
  modified charitable immunity as it applied to hospitals, was void ab initio 
  when it was declared unconstitutional in 1992.Â  As a result, the unconstitutional 
  1977 statute did not impact a suit brought against a hospital in 1998, given 
  that the plaintiffâ€™s cause of action accrued in 1979 and must be based on the 
  law as it existed.Â  This result was proper because there were no rights and 
  relationships that already had been determined and settled by past events and 
  transactions.

  When a statute is found unconstitutional, we have recognized the general 
    rule that an adjudication of [the] unconstitutionality of a statute ordinarily 
    reaches back to the date of the act itself. . . .Â Â Â  However, we also have 
    recognized the necessity of upholding the validity of transactions or events 
    that occurred before a statute was declared unconstitutional. . . . A close 
    reading of the few South Carolina cases discussing the general rule indicates 
    it is followed except in special or unusual circumstances, such as 
    when doing so would create widespread havoc involving a great number of people 
    or transactions, spawn unnecessary litigation, or result in flagrant injustice.

Bergstrom, 358 S.C. at 399-400, 596 S.E.2d 
  at 47-48 (citations and quotes omitted) (emphasis added).
In Bergstrom, we relied in part on the broad 
  principles set forth in Atkinson regarding the impact of a finding that 
  a statute is unconstitutional.Â  The issue in Atkinson was whether a recently 
  enacted federal statute revived certain state alcohol statutes, which previously 
  had been deemed unconstitutional because they violated federal interstate commerce 
  principles.Â  In explaining why the state statutes were not revived or validated 
  by the new federal act, the Court recited several principles emphasizing the 
  void nature of an unconstitutional statute.Â  Id. at 453, 78 S.E. at 519.Â  

The Atkinson Court was faced with the issue 
  of whether to grant an injunction to the plaintiff because the unconstitutional 
  statutes were of no import, i.e., the Court had to evaluate the partiesâ€™ present 
  rights and duties in light of the void statutes.Â  In contrast, the present case 
  requires us to examine past events and transactions in determining, first, 
  the impact a presumptively valid statute had on the partiesâ€™ then-existing contractual 
  rights and duties, and second, the impact a later finding of unconstitutionality 
  had on the then-existing rights and duties.Â  We recognize that the general principles 
  expressed in Atkinsonâ€”though inadequate to resolve the issues in this 
  caseâ€”are appropriate in other settings, and therefore we decline to overrule 
  that decision.Â  
 In sum, this case presents a special or unusual circumstance in which we must 
  uphold the validity of transactions or events that occurred before a statute 
  was declared unconstitutional.Â  The contract for video poker machines became 
  void and unenforceable by either party as of July 1, 1995, due to referenda 
  under the local option law and the revocation of the machine licenses by the 
  Department of Revenue.Â  Moreover, our finding that the local option law was 
  unconstitutionalâ€”sixteen months after the partiesâ€™ duty to perform under the 
  contract was discharged according to a long-established principle of contract 
  lawâ€”did not breathe life back into the contract.
Conclusion
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  For the foregoing reasons, we REVERSE 
  the court of appealsâ€™ decision and remand for entry of summary judgment in favor 
  of White on Brownâ€™s breach of contract counterclaim.Â  The trial court correctly 
  ruled that the sole subject matter of the contract was the outlawed video poker 
  machines.Â  Neither party breached the contract, and therefore neither party 
  is entitled to damages.
MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice Aphrodite K.. Konduros, 
  concur.


 
   
    [1]  The parties debate the meaning of the contractual term â€œcertain coin-operated 
    amusement machines.â€Â  We conclude that the trial court correctly relied on 
    the deposition testimonies of White and the Brown representative to determine 
    that this was a typical contract involving video poker machines at convenience 
    stores, a type of contract common in South Carolina at the time.Â  The parties 
    debate whether the judgeâ€™s finding was the unappealed law of the case, or 
    whether the contract also contemplated Pac-Man video games or the like.Â  Again, 
    we find that it was a contract for video poker machines.

 
   
    [2]  Whiteâ€™s two questions actually present only one question.Â  We also 
    note that this case does not raise any issue under the Contract Clause contained 
    in the state or federal constitutions, which prohibits the state from passing 
    laws which impair the obligation of contracts.Â  We have rejected such a claim 
    in connection with legislative control of video poker gambling.Â  Rickâ€™s 
    Amusement, Inc. v. State, 351 S.C. 352, 570 S.E.2d 155 (2001); Mibbs, 
    Inc. v. S.C. Dept. of Revenue, 337 S.C. 601, 524 S.E.2d 626 (1999).Â Â Â Â

title: Hall v. State
description: The Court, in this opinion, remanded petitioner's case for a new sentencing proceeding, finding his counsel ineffective for failing to object to the solicitor's closing argument comparing the worth of the petitioner's life with that of his victims.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Supreme Court

 
   
     
      
        Larry Eugene Hall, Petitioner,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        William D. Catoe, Director, South Carolina Department of Corrections, 
          Respondent. 
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Opinion No. 25850
  Submitted March 17, 2004 - Filed August 9, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED 

 
   
     
      
        Teresa L. Norris and Jerome H. Nickerson, of the Center of Capital 
          Litigation, both of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General 
          John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, 
          all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL: We granted certiorari 
  to determine whether the post-conviction relief (PCR) court erred by denying 
  inmate Larry Hall (â€œHallâ€) relief on the death sentence he received as a result 
  of a murder conviction.Â  We remand Hallâ€™s case for a new sentencing proceeding.
Factual/Procedural Background
In July 1991, Hall committed a series of crimes 
  in an Easley Wal-Mart parking lot.Â  To begin, Hall robbed and sexually assaulted 
  his first victim at gunpoint.Â  Hall then ordered her to walk to the back parking 
  lot with him.Â  A Wal-Mart employee noticed Hallâ€™s strange behavior and drove 
  a truck through Hall and the victimâ€™s path. Hall allowed her to escape and then 
  walked into the woods behind the store waving his gun in the air.
A half hour later, Hall approached two teenage girls, who were sisters, in 
  the back parking lot.Â  In front of numerous witnesses and without provocation, 
  Hall shot and killed the two girls.Â  When the police arrived and finally cornered 
  Hall, he challenged the police with a piece of wood and dared the police to 
  shoot him. 
Hall has both mental and physical disabilities.Â  
  He currently takes, and was taking during trial, Dilantin and Phenobarbital 
  to prevent epileptic seizures.Â  Dilantin has a sedative effect similar to the 
  effects of alcohol.Â  At the time of his arraignment, Hall had twice the amount 
  of Dilantin in his bloodstream than the normal therapeutic amount. 
  [1] Â  Hallâ€™s sister, mother, and former employer all testified that Hallâ€™s 
  seizures and medications make it very difficult for him to complete simple everyday 
  tasks and that he is often in a â€œdazeâ€ or â€œin the fog.â€Â  Hall has a â€œgrossly 
  abnormalâ€ EEG, [2]  as the result 
  of his having epilepsy.Â  
Hall has been diagnosed 
  with â€œsensory dysfunction,â€ deficient language abilities, and deficient organizational 
  abilities.Â  He suffers from both organic personality disorderâ€”which may cause 
  uncontrollable mood shifts and outbursts of aggressionâ€”and schizoid personality, 
  which makes Hall indifferent to praise or punishment.Â  Hall is also borderline 
  mentally retarded, having an IQ of 72.
In August 1991, six months 
  before Hallâ€™s trial, a group of doctors at the Hall Institute in Columbia evaluated 
  Hall and found him competent to stand trial.Â  One doctor, however, testified 
  that Hallâ€™s competency was â€œborderlineâ€ and a â€œtouch and goâ€ issue.Â Â  Hall was 
  not evaluated again before his trial.Â  
During closing argument, 
  the solicitor directed the jury to weigh the worth of Hallâ€™s life against the 
  lives of Hallâ€™s victims:Â  â€œ[w]hat are the lives of these two girls worth?Â  Are 
  they worth at least the life of a man, the psychopath, this killer who stabs 
  and stabs and kills and rapes and kidnaps?â€Â  Hall was then convicted of murder, 
  kidnapping, first-degree criminal sexual conduct, armed robbery, and resisting 
  arrest and was sentenced to death.
Hall subsequently applied for PCR, and the PCR judge denied relief directing 
  the state to draft an order, which the trial judge adopted in full, without 
  alterations.Â  This Court granted certiorari to review the following issues:

   
    I.
    
    Did the PCR judge err in applying a heightened burden of proof 
      to determine whether Hall was competent to stand trial?
    
  
   
    II.
    
    Was Hallâ€™s trial counsel ineffective for failing to object 
      to the solicitorâ€™s closing argument, which compared the worth of Hallâ€™s 
      life to the victimsâ€™ lives?
    
  
   
    III.
    
    Did the PCR judge err in adopting the stateâ€™s proposed order 
      in its entirety?
    
  

Law/Analysis
Standard of Review
This Court must determine whether any probative 
  evidence exists to support the denial of post-conviction relief.Â  Cherry 
  v. State, 300 S.C. 115, 119, 386 S.E.2d 624, 626 (1980).Â  If any probative 
  evidence exists, the PCR judgeâ€™s ruling should be upheld.Â  Id.
 I.       Competency 
  to Stand Trial
 A.Â  Burden of Proof
Hall argues that the PCR judge applied the wrong standard 
  of proof in deciding whether Hall was competent to stand trial.Â  We disagree.Â  

A defendant must prove that he is incompetent to stand trial by a â€œpreponderance 
  of the evidence.â€Â  State v. Reed, 332 S.C. 35, 39, 503 S.E.2d 747, 749 
  (1998).Â  Holding a criminal defendant to a â€œclear and convincingâ€ burden to 
  prove incompetence is a violation of due process.Â  Cooper v. Oklahoma, 
  517 U.S. 348, 350, 116 S. Ct. 1373, 1375, 134 L. Ed. 2d 498 (1996).Â  
In his order, the PCR judge stated 
  that Hall failed to establish â€œwith credible and convincing evidenceâ€ that he 
  was incompetent to stand trial.Â  Hall argues that â€œcredible and convincingâ€ 
  evidence is synonymous with â€œclear and convincingâ€ evidence, which is not the 
  appropriate standard of proof for determining a defendantâ€™s competency to stand 
  trial.Â  However, after reviewing the order in its entirety, we find that the 
  trial judge used the correct burden of proof - a preponderance of the evidence.Â  
  In fact, the PCR judge noted several times that Hall must prove his incompetence 
  by a â€œpreponderance of the evidence.â€Â  
First, in his order, the 
  PCR judge stated that â€œ[i]n a state post-conviction relief hearing, the Applicant 
  also bears the burden of proof and he is required to show by a preponderance 
  of the evidence that he is entitled to relief.Â  Rule 71.1(e), SCRCP.Â  This Court 
  finds that he has failed this burden.â€Â  
Second, in finding that 
  Hall was not prejudiced by ineffective assistance of counsel, the PCR judge 
  stated,Â  â€œHall has a burden of proof at trial to show by a preponderance of 
  the evidence that he was incompetent.Â  This Court finds, to a reasonable probability, 
  he has failed in his burden.â€Â  
We note that the PCR judgeâ€™s 
  order should have been amended to exclude the â€œcredible and convincingâ€ language, 
  alleviating any doubt concerning which standard the PCR judge applied.Â  Nevertheless, 
  after reviewing the order in its entirety, we find that the judge applied the 
  proper standardâ€”preponderance of the evidenceâ€”to determine whether Hall was 
  competent to stand trial.
B.Â  Evidence of Petitionerâ€™s Competency to Stand Trial
On July 16, 1991, three days 
  after Hallâ€™s arrest, the trial court ordered Hall to be evaluated for his competency 
  to stand trial.Â  A group of doctors at the Hall Institute found Hall to be competent 
  to stand trial, with one doctor reporting that Hallâ€™s mental state was a â€œclose 
  callâ€ and a â€œtouch and goâ€ issue.Â  Since the 1991 evaluations, the parties have 
  accumulated a mass of evidence and engaged in a â€œbattle of the expertsâ€ as to 
  Hallâ€™s competency to stand trial.Â  Hall argues that, although he was found competent 
  in August 1991, he was not competent during his trial, which took place in January 
  1992.Â  We find a sufficient amount of evidence supporting the PCR judgeâ€™s conclusion 
  that Hall was competent to stand trial.
Conviction of a criminal defendant 
  who is not competent to stand trial violates the due process clause of the fourteenth 
  amendment.Â  Pate v. Robinson, 383 U.S. 375 (1966).Â  This Court has held 
  that to be competent to stand trial or continue trial, a defendant must have 
  â€œa rational, as well as factual, understanding of the proceedings against himâ€ 
  and the â€œability to consult with his lawyer with a reasonable degree of rational 
  understanding.â€ State v. Bell, 293 S.C. 391, 395-96, 360 S.E.2d 706, 
  708 (1987) (citing Dusky v. United States, 362 U.S. 402, 402 (1960)).
If there is â€œany evidence of 
  probative value to support the post conviction judgeâ€™s factual findings,â€ we 
  must affirm.Â  Cherry, 300 S.C. at 119, 386 S.E.2d at 626.Â  Nevertheless, 
  if the PCR judge makes an error of law, then this Court must reverse.Â  Pierce 
  v. State, 338 S.C. 139, 145, 526 S.E.2d 222, 225 (2000).Â  In addition, the 
  PCR judge has the duty to weigh the credibility of the doctors who have testified 
  as to Hallâ€™s competency to stand trial.Â  If the testimony supports the PCR judgeâ€™s 
  findings, then the findings should be upheld.Â  Solomon v. State, 313 
  S.C. 526, 443 S.E.2d 540 (1994); Wade v. State, 308 S.C. 552, 419 S.E.2d 
  781 (1992) (a finding that testimony in support of allegations was unconvincing, 
  without credibility, and untruthful will be upheld on appeal).
This Court has held that the 
  PCR judge erred in granting relief on the basis that the defendant was not competent 
  to stand trial when (1) counsel testified at the PCR hearing that he had no 
  trouble communicating with the defendant; (2) the trial transcript showed that 
  the defendant clearly understood the questions asked and responded in an appropriate 
  manner; and (3) a forensic psychiatrist evaluated the defendant prior to trial 
  and found the defendantâ€™s medical conditions did not affect his mental state.Â  
  McLaughlin v. State, 352 S.C. 476, 575 S.E.2d 841 (2002).Â  
Hall presents several arguments 
  that he was incompetent to stand trial:Â  (1) he has been diagnosed with an antisocial 
  disorder; (2) his trial counsel testified that he believed that Hall was not 
  competent during trial; (3) Hall suffered from a seizure the night before sentencing, 
  indicating that he could have experienced periods of incompetency; (4) during 
  trial, he had taken abnormal doses of Dilantin causing him to be groggy and 
  sedated; and (5) his low IQ indicates he has the intelligence of an average 
  eleven-year-old. 
Conversely, the state presents 
  a sufficient amount of probative evidence that Hall was competent to stand trial:Â  
  (1) in August 1991, several psychologists conducted an extensive evaluation 
  of Hall and found him to be competent to stand trial; (2) Dr. McKee, who evaluated 
  Hall from July 23, 1991 to August 8, 1991, found that â€œhis answers to his questions 
  were well associated, goal directed and relevant; there was no evidence of delusional 
  thinkingâ€ and that he was capable of â€œunderstanding and participating in his 
  defense and is capable of understanding the charges against himâ€;Â  (3) one of 
  Hallâ€™s defense counsel, Dallas Ball, testified in a May 29, 1997 deposition 
  that â€œ[i]n the discussions with Mr. Hall throughout the caseâ€¦[Hall] understood 
  what he was facing, and he listened to the testimony each day as to what was 
  said against him, and he understood what was going onâ€; (4)Â  during the PCR 
  hearing, defense counsel, Christopher Olson (Olson), testified that Hall told 
  him that he shot the other girl because she was an eyewitness to the first shooting, 
  indicating that Hall knew the consequences of his actions; and (5) Olson also 
  testified that none of the doctors indicated any need to reevaluate Hall before 
  trial. 
We find that a sufficient amount 
  of probative evidence exists to support the PCR judgeâ€™s ruling that Hall was 
  competent to stand trial.Â  Moreover, given that the PCR applied the correct 
  burden of proof, we hold that the PCR judge correctly determined that Hall was 
  competent to stand trial.
II.Â  Closing Argument
Hall argues that trial counsel 
  was ineffective because counsel failed to object when the solicitor made the 
  following statement in his closing argument:

  I am talking about values, because a jury verdict is a statement of values.Â  
    And I am not talking about dollars and cents as far as what the [lives of 
    the two girls were] worth, but nevertheless it is a question of values.Â  What 
    are the lives of these two girls worth?Â  Are they worth the life of this man, 
    the psychopath, this killer who stabs and stabs and kills, and rapes and kidnaps.

Hall argues that his trial counselâ€™s 
  failure to object allowed the solicitor to charge the jury with an arbitrary, 
  misconceived sentencing analysis, violating Hallâ€™s right to due process.Â  We 
  agree. 
A criminal defendant is constitutionally 
  entitled to effective representation.Â  Rogers v. State, 261 S.C. 288, 
  199 S.E.2d 761 (1973).Â  In order to find trial counsel ineffective, this Court 
  must find that counselâ€™s conduct was deficient and that the deficiency prejudiced 
  the outcome of the trial.Â  Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668 (1984). 

In the past, the United States 
  Supreme Court (USSC) did not explicitly recognize the stateâ€™s right to offer 
  victim impact evidence in a criminal trial.Â  In Booth v. Maryland, the 
  USSC â€œleft open the possibility that the kind of information contained in victim 
  impact statements could be admissible if it â€˜related directly to the circumstances 
  of the crime.â€™â€ 482 U.S. 496, 507 (1987)).Â  Additionally, in South Carolina 
  v. Gathers, the USSC affirmed this Courtâ€™s ruling that â€œvictim impact statements 
  in capital sentencing proceeds violate [the] principle that a sentence of death 
  must be related to the moral culpability of the defendant.â€Â  490 U.S. 805, 810 
  (1989).Â  
But in 1991, the USSC overruled 
  Gathers and Booth, holding:

  if the State chooses to permit the admission of victim impact evidence and 
    prosecutorial argument on that subject, the Eighth Amendment erects no per 
    se bar.Â  A state may legitimately conclude that evidence about the victim 
    and about the impact of the murder on the victimâ€™s family is relevant to the 
    juryâ€™s decision as to whether or not the death penalty should be imposed.Â  
    There is no reason to treat such evidence differently than any other relevant 
    evidence is treated.

Payne v. Tennessee, 501 U.S. 808, 827 (1991).
In other words, â€œ[v]ictim impact 
  evidence, as any other relevant evidence, is admissible so long as it is not 
  so unduly prejudicial that it renders the trial fundamentally unfairâ€¦.â€ Id.Â  
  However, â€œ[a]s a general matter, â€¦ victim impact evidence is not offered 
  to encourage comparative judgments of this kindâ€”for instance, that the killer 
  of a hardworking, devoted parent deserves the death penalty, but that the murderer 
  of a reprobate does not.â€ Id. at 823, 111 S. Ct. at 2607 (emphasis added).Â  
  Under a similar line of reasoning, this Court held that a criminal defendantâ€™s 
  reprehensibility was not mitigated by the fact that the victim was a murderer 
  himself.Â  State v. Gaskins, 284 S.C. 105, 326 S.E.2d 132 (1985).
At first glance, our decision in Humphries v. 
  State appears to allow a solicitor to compare the lives of a criminal defendant 
  with that of the defendantâ€™s victim.Â  351 S.C. 362, 376, 570 S.E.2d 160, 168 
  (2002).Â  Nonetheless, we do not extend Humphries to permit the state 
  to encourage the jury to compare the worth of a defendantâ€™s life with that of 
  his victims. In Humphries, we upheld Humphriesâ€™s death sentence and held 
  that the solicitorâ€™s comparison of the lives of Humphries and his victim was 
  within the realm of permissible victim impact evidence.Â  In Humphries, 
  defense counsel, attempting to mitigate the effects of the stateâ€™s evidence 
  concerning the brutality of the murder, elicited testimony that Humphries was 
  a victim of parental abuse, substance abuse, and poverty as a child. 
  [3]  Â Â 
In his closing argument, the solicitor responded 
  by comparing the lives of Humphries and his victim.Â  Although both Humphries 
  and his victim were reared in impoverished conditions, Humphries was in and 
  out of jail while the victim maintained an ordinary, crime-free life.Â  We held 
  that the solicitorâ€™s argument was permissible victim impact evidence.  
  [4] Â  
Again, the solicitorâ€™s argument in Hallâ€™s trial 
  is distinguishable from the solicitorâ€™s argument in Humphries.Â  
In Humphries we recognized that it is more prejudicial for the state 
  to compare the worth of the life of the defendant with that of his victim than 
  it is to compare their lives based on the evidence presented.Â  Id. at 
  374, 570 S.E.2d at 167-168.Â  In the present case, the solicitor not only suggested 
  that Hallâ€™s life was worth less than his victimsâ€™, he developed an arbitrary 
  formula whereby if the jury finds Hallâ€™s life worth less than his victimsâ€™, 
  then the jury could reach no other conclusion than that the death penalty is 
  justified.Â  
Further, while the solicitor in Humphries compared the histories 
  of Humphriesâ€™s and his victimâ€™s lives, the solicitor in Hall asked the 
  jury to compare the worth of Hallâ€™s life with that of his victimsâ€™. 

We hold that the solicitor impermissibly compared 
  Hallâ€™s life to the victimsâ€™ lives.Â  We find that the solicitorâ€™s comparison 
  (1) was so emotionally inflammatory that it became a material part of the juryâ€™s 
  deliberation process;Â  (2) unquestionably directed the jurors to conduct an 
  arbitrary balancing of worth, which required that Hall be sentenced to death 
  if the jury found Hallâ€™s life was worth less than the lives of his victims; 
  (3) is totally unrelated to the circumstances of the crime; and (4) is distinguishable 
  from traditional impact evidence in that it was not actually offered to show 
  the impact of the crime on the victims or the victimsâ€™ family.Â  
For these reasons, we hold that Hall was denied his constitutional right to 
  effective assistance of counsel when his trial counsel failed to object to the 
  solicitorâ€™s comparison between the worth of Hallâ€™s life and the lives of the 
  victims.
III.Â  Adoption of the Stateâ€™s Proposed Order in Full
Hall argues that the PCR judge erred in adopting 
  the stateâ€™s proposed order because the order did not resolve issues of fact, 
  indicating that the judge did not render an independent judicial judgment.Â  
  We disagree.Â  
The commentary to South Carolina Appellate Court Rule 501, Canon 3 B(7)(e) 
  provides that â€œ[a] judge may request a party to submit proposed findings of 
  fact and conclusions of law, so long as the other parties are apprised of the 
  request and are given an opportunity to respond to the proposed findings and 
  conclusions.â€Â  Further, in Pruitt v. State, this Court directed that:Â  


  [c]ounsel preparing a proposed order should be meticulous in doing so, opposing 
    counsel should call any omissions to the attention of the PCR judge prior 
    to issuance of the order, and the PCR judge should carefully review the order 
    prior to signing it.Â  Moreover, after an order is filed, counsel has an obligation 
    to review the order and file a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion to alter or amend 
    if the order fails to set forth the findings and the reasons for those findings 
    as required by Â§ 17-27-80 and Rule 52(a), SCRCPâ€¦.

310 S.C. 254, 256, 423 S.E.2d 127, 128 (1992).
On November 12, 1999, after receiving a request from the PCR judge to do so, 
  the state submitted a proposed order to both the judge and opposing counsel.Â  
  On November 14, 1999, the PCR judge told the parties that he would â€œcarefully 
  review the proposed order and insure that the facts and conclusions of law are 
  as I find them to be.â€Â  
Although we strongly encourage PCR judges to draft their own findings of fact 
  and conclusions of law in death penalty cases, we also acknowledge that in all 
  other cases, it is common practice for judges to ask a party to draft a proposed 
  order for the sake of efficiency.Â  In the present case, the evidence sufficiently 
  indicates that the PCR judge spent an adequate amount of time reviewing the 
  order before adopting it.Â  Further, Hall waived his right to make this challenge 
  when he failed to file a motion to alter or amend the order. Id.Â 
Conclusion
We REVERSE the PCR court on the basis that Hallâ€™s 
  counsel was ineffective for not objecting to the solicitorâ€™s closing argument, 
  which included an instruction to the jury to compare the worth of Hallâ€™s life 
  with the lives of his victims. Accordingly, we REMAND for a new sentencing proceeding.Â  
  Finally, we affirm the PCR judgeâ€™s ruling on the remaining issues.
MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.


 
   
    [1]  Dr. James Brice, Hallâ€™s family physician, saw Hall shortly after 
    the court hearing.Â  Dr. Brice ordered blood tests, which revealed that Hallâ€™s 
    Dilantin level was 39.Â  The normal therapeutic range is 10-20.Â  

 
    [2]  An EEG (electroencephalograph) 
    monitors the electric impulses of the brain, allowing doctors to detect and 
    diagnose brain dysfunction.

 
   
    [3]  Humphries presented thirteen witnesses who testified as to his cruel 
    childhood.Â  

 
    [4]  We recognize that the 
    Fourth Circuit recently granted Humphries federal habeas corpus, finding that 
    the state (1) compared the worth of Humphriesâ€™s life with that of his 
    victim and (2) did so for the primary purpose of â€œexhort[ing] the jury to 
    return a death sentence on the basis of the [defendantâ€™s] relative lack of 
    worth.â€Â  Humphries v. Ozmint, 2004 WL 937266 at 4 (4th Cir. 
    May 3, 2004).Â  We also take notice that the Fourth Circuit granted the stateâ€™s 
    petition for rehearing en banc and will rehear the case in October 
    2004.Â  Nevertheless, we disagree that the victim-defendant comparison found 
    in our account of Humphries is as prejudicial as the comparison in 
    the present case.Â  We continue to distinguish the facts of Humphries 
    with that of the present case and maintain that these factual differences 
    yield a different result as a matter of law.Â  Our interpretation of the law 
    coincides most congruently with Senior Judge Hamiltonâ€™s dissent in the Fourth 
    Circuitâ€™s recent account of Humphries:Â  


  [A]llowing the introduction of victim-impact evidence does not, 
    and should not, open the door to evidence/argument ultimately allowing the 
    jury to make a comparative inquiry between the victim and other victims in 
    society, as the court in Payne apparently recognized.
  â€¦
  Put simply, clearly established Supreme Court precedent does not 
    prohibit victim-to-defendant comparisons; they are inevitable in any capital 
    case in which the jury is asked to assess the persuasive force of the defendantâ€™s 
    mitigating evidence and the victim-impact evidence. 


  Id. at 18.Â  
  We recognize that those victim-to-defendant comparisons that render a trial 
    fundamentally unfair and those victim-to-defendant comparisons that are permissible 
    are not always clearly distinguishable.Â  A comparison that constitutes permissible 
    victim-impact evidence is not as prejudicial to a defendant as a comparison 
    that imposes, what in effect is, an arbitrary, unfounded jury charge.Â

title: Collins Holding Corporation v. Landrum
description: The Court affirmed an order awarding the plaintiff damages in this breach of contract action.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Supreme Court

 
   
     
      
        Collins Holding Corporation, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        Scott Landrum and Landrum Incorporated, Inc., Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
  Â C. Victor Pyle, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25851
  Heard June 22, 2004 - Filed August 9, 2004

AFFIRMED

 
   
     
      
        Robin B. Stilwell, of Greenville, for Appellant.
        John S. Nichols, of Bluestein & Nichols, LLC, of Columbia, and 
          Ralph Lee Gleaton, II, of Pfeiffer & Gantt, PA, of Greenville, for 
          Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  Collins Holding Corporation (Collins) filed a breach 
  of contract action against Landrum Inc. and Scott Landrum (collectively Appellant). [1] Â  After a bench trial, the judge awarded Collins 
  $244,450.56 in damages.Â  Both Collins and Appellant moved to alter or amend 
  the order.Â  The judge denied the motions.Â  Appellant appealed.Â  This appeal 
  was certified from the Court of Appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â  We 
  affirm.
FACTS
On December 21, 2000, Appellant 
  and Collins signed a contract that gave Collins â€œthe exclusive right for six 
  years to install and maintain all coin and/or currency operated Flipper Machines, 
  and Pinball Machines, upon the entire premises of [three convenience stores 
  owned by Appellant].â€Â  The contract also stated that Appellant had the right 
  to have the machines removed with 10 days written notice to Collins.Â  The revenue 
  was to be divided 40% to Appellant and 60% to Collins.Â  The contract stated 
  â€œ[d]uring the term and any continuation thereof, no other person, firm, corporation 
  or entity of any kind whatsoever shall have the right to operate any [] coin 
  and/or currency operated flipper machines and pinball machines, upon said premises.â€Â  
  Finally, the contract also stated â€œ[a]ny prior statements, offers, representations 
  or understandings are deemed matters of negotiation only and are merged into 
  this Agreement which is a complete integration of the Agreement and contains 
  only the Agreement between the parties regarding the subject matter described 
  herein.Â  [Appellant] further certifies that there are no contracts or agreements 
  with any other party regarding the subject matter herein.Â  This Agreement may 
  only be modified by a written instrument signed by all the parties hereto.â€Â  
  Both parties, as well as two witnesses, signed the agreement.Â  
The judge found that Appellant became dissatisfied with the 60/40 split of 
  revenues and demanded a 50/50 split, which Collins refused.Â  After the refusal, 
  Appellant disconnected Collinsâ€™ machines and installed his own machines, as 
  well as machines owned by Sonco Amusements, Inc. (Sonco). Sonco split the revenues 
  50/50 with Appellant. The judge found that Appellant breached the contract with 
  Collins and awarded Collins $244,450.56 in damages as well as the costs of the 
  action.Â  
 ISSUES
1.Â  Did the trial court err in awarding Collins damages for breach of contract 
  because the damages were too speculative?
2.Â  Did the trial court err in not awarding Appellant damages for breach of 
  contract?
ANALYSIS
1.Â  Speculative Damages
Appellant argues that the trial judge erred in awarding Collins damages because 
  any damages are speculative.Â  We disagree.Â  The trial judge based his award 
  of damages on the testimony of Jerry Alex Saad (Saad), a Certified Public Accountant, 
  who had previously been the Chief Financial Officer for Collins Entertainment 
  for 8 years.Â  Saad testified that the damages suffered by Collins in this case 
  were $244,450.56.Â  Saad reached this figure by taking the actual weekly revenues 
  received from each location owned by Appellant for the period of time that the 
  machines were in Appellantâ€™s stores. He took a weekly average using that figure 
  and multiplied that average by the number of weeks remaining in the term of 
  that locationâ€™s contract.Â  
Appellant argues that the 
  damages are speculative. He argues that because he exercised the contract provision 
  that allowed the machines to be removed after 10 days written notice, there 
  would be no revenue, and therefore no damages.Â  Although Appellant is correct 
  that the contract allowed the machines to be removed with 10 days written notice, 
  he is incorrect in his assertion that this clause affects the damages.Â  The 
  breach of contract occurred when Appellant placed â€œforeignâ€ machines, which 
  were not owned by Collins, in the stores.Â  According to the contract, Collins 
  had the exclusive right to provide flipper machines in the stores for 6 years.Â  

In a breach of contract 
  action, the â€œmeasure of damages is the loss actually suffered by the contractee 
  as the result of the breach. And profits that have been prevented or lost as 
  the natural consequence of a breach of contract are recoverable as an item of 
  damages in an action for such breach.â€Â  South Carolina Finance Corp. of Anderson 
  v. West Side Finance Comp., 236 S.C. 109, 114, 113 S.E.2d 329, 335-36 (1960).Â  
  Saad testified about the formula used to calculate the estimated damages, and 
  the formula is reasonable.Â  â€œThe law does not require absolute certainty of 
  data upon which lost profits are to be estimated, but all that is required is 
  such reasonable certainty that damages may not be based wholly upon speculation 
  or conjecture, and it is sufficient if there is a certain standard or fixed 
  method by which profits sought to be recovered may be estimated and determined 
  with a fair degree of accuracy.â€Â  113 S.E.2d at 336.Â  We affirm the trial courtâ€™s 
  award of $244,450.56 for Appellantâ€™s breach of contract.Â  
2.Â  Appellantâ€™s Damages
Appellant alleges that the machines were not removed 10 days after he gave 
  Collins written notice, and therefore Collins breached the contract.Â  Appellant 
  contends the trial court erred in not awarding him damages.Â  We disagree.
Appellant testified he notified Collins that he wanted the machines removed 
  but Collins did not remove the machines until 6 months after notification.Â  
  Appellant testified that he was forced to store the machines for this period 
  and that he could have used the area for storage. Appellant figured his damages 
  at $10 a day for 6 months, which is $3,600.Â  The judge found that Appellant 
  failed to prove his claim by the greater weight of the evidence and did not 
  award Appellant damages.Â  We affirm the trial judge.Â  Appellant was unable to 
  locate a copy of the letter that he sent to Collins.Â  Further, Appellant did 
  not offer any evidence to prove damages, except that he â€œcould have had merchandise 
  there overstocked.â€Â  The trial courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.Â  
MOORE and WALLER., JJ., concur.Â  TOAL, C.J., concurring in part and dissenting 
  in part in a separate opinion in which Acting Justice Aphrodite K. Konduros, 
  concurs.

 
CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  I agree with the majorityâ€™s holding that the damage 
  award in favor of Collins was not speculative, but I disagree with the majorityâ€™s 
  conclusion that the Appellant did not satisfy his burden of proving that Collins 
  breached the contract causing Appellant to suffer damages.Â  Therefore, I respectfully 
  dissent in part.
The contract between Appellant and Collins provided that the Appellant had 
  â€œthe right to have said machines removed within (10) ten days written notice 
  toâ€ Collins.Â  While Appellant may have been unable to include in the record 
  the letters he sent to Collins giving the ten day notice, [2]  Collins testified about the contents of two notice letters 
  on cross-examination: 
 
  Appellant: Mr. Collins, I want to show you two letters â€¦ [y]ou are welcome 
    to read them into the record, should you elect to, sir.
  Collins: This is July the 31st, 2001.Â  And itâ€™s a letter from 
    [Appellantâ€™s attorney] to [Collinsâ€™ attorney].
  â€œDear [Collinsâ€™ attorney], Iâ€™ve had the opportunity to review your July 24th, 
    2001, correspondence regarding the above-referenced store and related contract.Â  
    Pursuant to the specific terms of the contract, [Appellant] would respectfully 
    request that [Collins] remove its machines from all relevant locations within 
    10 days of the date of this letter.â€
  â€¦
  Appellant: Now under the terms of this contract, does that count as notice 
    --
  Collins: That would be notice, yes, sir.
  â€¦
  Appellant: All right sir.Â  And the second one, does it essentially ask for 
    the --
  Collins: This is August the 31st, 2001.
  â€¦
  â€œDear [Collinsâ€™ attorney], I received your recent letter regarding the above-referenced 
    matter.Â  To date, your client has not removed the machines as contemplated 
    under the contract.Â  Please be advised that your client has 10 days from the 
    date of this letter to remove the machines or they will simply be placed at 
    curbside for appropriate removal.â€
  â€¦
  Appellant: So you did get notice; right?
  Collins: My lawyer did, yes, sir.Â  And essentially, I got the notice because 
    he was representing me.

In my view, this testimony on cross-examination 
  clearly indicates that Collins received the requisite notice of Appellantâ€™s 
  contractual right to have the machines removed.Â  That evidence, combined with 
  Appellantâ€™s testimony of his inventory carrying cost -- a normal business expense 
  -- clearly satisfies Appellantâ€™s burden to prove both breach and damages.Â  
Accordingly, I would find that the trial judge erred in not awarding Appellant 
  damages in the amount of $3,600 [3]  resulting from Collinsâ€™ failure to remove the 
  machines.Â Â  
Acting Justice Aphrodite K. Konduros, concurs.


 
   [1]  Scott Landrum was dismissed from the case.Â  

 
   
    [2]  The letters, admitted into evidence as Defendantâ€™s Exhibit No. 2, 
    were lost by the Greenville County Clerk of Court.

 
   [3]  This amount was not disputed by Collins.Â

title: BB&T v. Fleming
description: The Court in this opinion held that an attorney of record may sign the verified statement of account in a collection matter.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Supreme Court

 
   
     
      
        BB&T of South Carolina, Petitioner,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        Lottie Fleming and Frederick Fleming, Respondents.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Greenville County
  Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25853
  Submitted April 21, 2004 - Filed August 9, 2004

REVERSED

 
   
     
      
        John William Ray, of Greenville, for Petitioner.
        Lottie Fleming and Frederick Fleming, of Greenville, pro se.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  We granted certiorari to determine whether 
  the court of appeals erred in affirming judgment for Lottie Fleming and Frederick 
  Fleming (Flemings), holding that a verified statement of account (VSA) included 
  in a request for default judgment cannot be signed by the attorney of record.Â  
  We reverse.
Factual/Procedural Background
In 1994, John William Ray 
  (Ray) began representing petitioner BB&T in its collection matters on a 
  large scale.Â  Regardless of whether BB&T sues a defaulted obligor, the obligorâ€™s 
  file remains in Rayâ€™s custody throughout the collection process.Â Â  Upon initiating 
  litigation against a defaulted obligor, Ray has developed a practice of attaching 
  a self-signed VSA, among other associated documents, to complaints.Â  In addition, 
  Ray has made practice of attaching a self-signed affidavit of the liquidated 
  sum certain along with interest and costs pursuant to Rule 55(b), SCRCP.Â  
From 1994 until 2000, Rayâ€™s practice of signing 
  the VSAs himself went unchallenged but in early 2000, in Greenville County, 
  BB&Tâ€™s requests for default judgment began to be denied.Â  At that same time, 
  the trial judge [1]  wrote Ray 
  and explained that the requests were being denied because VSAs â€œshould be signed 
  by [the] plaintiff,â€ not counsel.Â  In addition, the trial judgeâ€™s law clerk 
  wrote Ray a letter, explaining that Ray should not sign the VSAs because by 
  signing the VSAs, Ray was attesting â€œas a fact witnessâ€”which runs counter to 
  Rule 3.7.â€ [2] Â Â  
In response, Ray wrote the trial judge on two separate 
  occasions explaining that he was in the best position to sign the VSAs because 
  he was essentially the records custodian for BB&T.Â  The trial judge replied 
  to one of Rayâ€™s letters by writing:

  Everyday I sign orders for numerous collection attorneys from around the 
    stateâ€”None of those sign verifying the amount due.Â  You cannot do that as 
    an attorney in this case.Â  You are the only lawyer attempting to do thatâ€”Iâ€™m 
    sure that this is improper.Â  It is contrary to the law.Â  You cannot be a witness 
    in the case.Â  You present evidence.

The trial judge also wrote a letter to the Greenville County Clerk of Court, 
  which intercepted a letter that Ray wrote to the clerk stating:Â  â€œMr. Ray refuses 
  to handle his collection the way other attorneys do.Â  He cannot be a witness 
  and certify damages.Â  If he has the bank certify the amount due I will sign 
  the order.Â  If another Judge wants to sign it, fine.â€Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Subsequently, Ray wrote a letter to Judge Kittredgeâ€™s law 
  clerk to check the status of several proposed default orders that Ray had sent 
  for Judge Kittredgeâ€™s approval.Â  Judge Patterson responded to the letter:
 
  I am sorry that I am late in responding to your letter to Judge Kittredge, 
    but, as you know, I have relayed to you my opinion on this matter.
  Rule 11 permits signing of pleadings by attorneys.Â  Specifically, SCRCP 9(i) 
    provides for verification of account.Â  The Rule specifically states that the 
    pleader shall attach a verified copy of the account to the pleading.Â  It was 
    added to the South Carolina Rules to preserve prior practice.Â  These rules 
    never intended for an attorney to verify pleadings or accounts.Â  Further, 
    there is case law to the effect that an account based on information and belief 
    does not constitute proof sufficient to enter judgment for liquidated damages.Â  
    Rule 11(c) provides that when a corporation is a party the verification may 
    be made by any officer or agent thereof.Â  
  I have signed several hundred default judgments this year.Â  You are the only 
    attorney who does not have an officer or agent verify the amount of the loan, 
    the amount paid, and the balance due.
  Your files are becoming dormant, and in fairness, I shall set them before 
    me for a hearing, make a record, and permit you to appeal my ruling.

The letter was carbon-copied to Judges Few, Floyd, Kittredge, Watson, Cole, 
  and Non-jury Coordinator, Carole C. Hopkins.
Nearly a year later, the trial judgeâ€”before conducting a hearingâ€”issued an 
  order addressing five collection actions filed by Ray, including the Flemingsâ€™ 
  case.Â Â  In his order, the trial judge (1) refused to enter default judgment 
  in all cases where Ray signed the VSA and (2) imposed a proactive $100 fine 
  sua sponte against Ray for every future VSA that he signed and submitted 
  to the court.Â  
The court of appeals affirmed, holding that (1) the issue of whether Rayâ€™s 
  self-signed VSAs were legitimate was not preserved for review, and (2) the issue 
  concerning the trial judgeâ€™s proactive fines was not ripe for review.Â  BB&T 
  raises the following issues for review:

   
    I. 
    Did the court of appeals err in holding that the issue 
      of whether the trial judge properly refused to enter a default judgment 
      was not preserved for review?
  
   
    II. 
    Did the court of appeals err in holding that the issue 
      concerning proactive sanctions was not ripe for review? 
  

Law/Analysis
I.Â  Refusal to Enter Default Judgment
The court of appeals held that BB&T did not properly preserve 
  the issue of whether the trial judge erred in refusing to enter a default judgment 
  because the issue was â€œnot raised to the circuit court and [is] not addressed 
  in the order.â€ BB&T of South Carolina v. Lottie Fleming and Frederick 
  Fleming, Op. No. 03-UP-255 (S.C. Ct. App. filed April 8, 2003).Â  BB&T 
  argues that the court of appeals erred in ruling that the issue was not properly 
  preserved for review.Â  BB&T further argues that the court of appeals should 
  have reversed the trial judgeâ€™s ruling denying BB&T default judgment.Â  We 
  agree.
In early October 2000, the trial judge wrote Ray a letter explaining that he 
  intended to conduct a hearing and create a record so that the VSA issue would 
  be preserved for review, but a hearing never took place.Â  In addition, the record 
  reveals that BB&T offered to prepare a record and an order to the trial 
  courtâ€™s specification.Â  Nevertheless, the trial judge rejected BB&Tâ€™s proposals 
  and failed to address the VSA issue in the order despite BB&Tâ€™s efforts 
  to have the issue placed on the record.Â  As a result, BB&T could not create 
  a record and preserve the issue for review.Â  Given that BB&T took the proper 
  steps to preserve the issue, and was unsuccessful only because of the trial 
  courtâ€™s lack of cooperation, we hold that the VSA issue is properly preserved 
  for appellate review and will address the issue accordingly.
Two rules apply to the VSA issue presented in this case:Â  
  Rule 9(i), SCRCP, Verification of Account and Rule 11(c), SCRCP, Affidavits 
  and Verifications.

  Rule 9(i), SCRCP, provides:
  Verification of Account.Â  In an action on an account the pleader shall 
    attach a verified copy of the account to the pleading, or if the items of 
    the account are set forth in the pleading, it must be verified.
  Rule 11(c), SCRCP, provides:
  Affidavits and Verifications.Â  Affidavits or verifications authorized 
    or permitted under these Rules shall be written statements or declarations 
    by a party or his attorney of record or of a witness, sworn to or affirmed 
    before an officer authorized to administer oaths, that the affiant knows the 
    facts stated to be true of his own knowledge, except as to those matters stated 
    on information and belief and as to those matters that he believes them to 
    be true.Â  When a corporation is a party the verifications may be made by any 
    officer or agent thereofâ€¦.

(emphasis added).Â  
In the present case, Ray is the attorney of record, and as 
  such, he is also an agent of BB&T.Â  Ray has also shown that he is in the 
  best position to sign VSAs for BB&T because he is the custodian of BB&Tâ€™s 
  obligor files. Accordingly, we hold that Rule 11(c) allows an attorney of record 
  to sign VSAs in connection with debt collection proceedings. Further, we find 
  that the trial judgeâ€™s grounds for denying judgment were based upon a misinterpretation 
  of the law and that default judgment should have been entered as requested.
We find that the court of appeals erred in holding that BB&T 
  did not properly preserve the issue of whether BB&Tâ€™s counsel may sign a 
  VSA.Â  In addition, according to the plain meaning of Rule 11(c), default judgment 
  should have been entered in favor of BB&T in its suit against the Flemings.
II.Â  Sanctions
BB&T argues that the court of appeals erred in affirming 
  the $100 proactive fine imposed by the trial judge.Â  Because the grounds for 
  the fines were based upon a misinterpretation of law, we hold that the sanctions 
  are void.Â  
Conclusion
We reverse the court of appeals ruling, which upholds the trial courtâ€™s denial 
  of entry of judgment based upon a misinterpretation of Rule 11(c), SCRCP.Â  We 
  also vacate the order as to sanctions against Ray and instruct the trial court 
  to enter judgment in favor of BB&T.
MOORE, WALLER and BURNETT, JJ., concur.Â  PLEICONES, J., not participating.


 
   
    [1]  Judge Patterson was the trial judge in the majority of the suits 
    involved in this appeal.Â  He was the first judge to deny Rayâ€™s requests for 
    default on the ground that the VSAs were â€œdefective.â€Â  As Chief Administrative 
    Judge of the thirteenth circuit, Judge Patterson also instructed the other 
    thirteenth circuit judges to deny all of Rayâ€™s requests for judgment that 
    included â€œdefectiveâ€ VSAs. 

 
   [2] Rule 3.7 of the Rules 
    of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR provides that an attorney may not 
    participate in a case if that attorney is likely to be a â€œnecessary witness.â€Â

  The Supreme Court of South Carolina
  In the Matter of Thomas E. Ruffin, 
    Jr., Respondent.
  
  ORDER
  
  The Office of Disciplinary 
    Counsel has filed a petition asking this Court to place respondent on interim 
    suspension pursuant to Rule 17(b), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, and seeking the 
    appointment of an attorney to protect clients' interests pursuant to Rule 
    31, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.
  IT IS ORDERED that 
    respondent's license to practice law in this state is suspended until further 
    order of the Court.
  IT IS FURTHER ORDERED 
    that James Thomas Young, Esquire, is hereby appointed to assume responsibility 
    for respondent's client files, trust account(s), escrow account(s), operating 
    account(s), and any other law office account(s) respondent may maintain. Mr. 
    Young shall take action as required by Rule 31, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, to 
    protect the interests of respondent's clients. Mr. Young may make disbursements 
    from respondent's trust account(s), escrow account(s), operating account(s), 
    and any other law office account(s) respondent may maintain that are necessary 
    to effectuate this appointment.
  This Order, when served 
    on any bank or other financial institution maintaining trust, escrow and/or 
    operating accounts of respondent, shall serve as an injunction to prevent 
    respondent from making withdrawals from the account(s) and shall further serve 
    as notice to the bank or other financial institution that James Thomas Young, 
    Esquire, has been duly appointed by this Court.
  Finally, this Order, 
    when served on any office of the United States Postal Service, shall serve 
    as notice that James Thomas Young, Esquire, has been duly appointed by this 
    Court and has the authority to receive respondent's mail and the authority 
    to direct that respondent's mail be delivered to Mr. Young's office. 
  This appointment shall 
    be for a period of no longer than nine months unless a request is made to 
    this Court for an extension.
  IT IS SO ORDERED.

        Moore        A.C.J.
