THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Brackenbrook North Charleston, LP, North Bluff North Charleston, LP,
Riverwoods, LLC, Ashley Arbor, LLC, et al.,       
Respondents/Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
The County of Charleston, Andrew Smith in his official capacity as Charleston 
        County Treasurer, Peggy A. Moseley in her official capacity as Charleston 
        County Auditor, and D. Michael Huggins in his official capacity as Charleston 
        County Assessor,        Appellants/Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
A. Victor Rawl, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25855
Heard April 20, 2004 - Filed August 
  16, 2004

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Joseph Dawson, III, and Bernard Ferrara, Jr., both of Charleston County Attorneyâ€™s 
  Office, of North Charleston; M. Dawes Cooke, Jr., and P. Gunnar Nistad, both 
  of Barnwell, Whaley, Patterson & Helms, LLC, of Charleston, for Appellants/Respondents.
G. Trenholm Walker, Andrew K. Epting, and Amanda R. Maybank, all of Pratt-Thomas, 
  Epting & Walker, PA, of Charleston, for Respondent/Appellants.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  Respondents/appellants (Taxpayers) filed 
  this action against appellants/respondents (County) 
  [1]  seeking a refund of a portion of their 2001 real property taxes.Â  The 
  parties appeal orders which, among other things, held that Taxpayers were not 
  required to exhaust their administrative remedies prior to bringing this refund 
  action directly in circuit court.Â  We hold this ruling was error, and reverse 
  and remand the matter to circuit court with instructions to dismiss the suit 
  without prejudice to Taxpayersâ€™ rights to pursue refunds through administrative 
  channels.
FACTS
A countywide appraisal resulted in large increases in the assessed 
  value of many real properties located in County.Â  In May 2000, the General Assembly 
  passed an act (Enabling Act) authorizing counties to exempt from ad valorem 
  property taxes any increase in valuation greater than 15%.Â  See S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 12-37-223A (Supp. 2003).Â  In November 2000, County adopted Ordinance 
  1163 (Ordinance), purportedly pursuant to the Enabling Act.Â  The Ordinance capped 
  the valuation increase on owner-occupied primary residences at 15%, but provided 
  no relief for other properties. [2] 
The â€œproperty tax assessmentâ€
(PTA) for each parcel of taxable real estate in a county is determined by
multiplying the propertyâ€™s fair market value or special use value by the appropriate assessment ratio, that is, 4% for owner-occupied 
  residences and 6% for other properties.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-60-30(19) (2000 
  and Supp. 2003).Â  This PTA figure is then multiplied by the taxing districtâ€™s [3]  millage rate, resulting in the tax assessment, that is, the 
  dollar amount owed by the taxpayer for that year. [4] Â  The millage is determined by dividing the 
  value of all taxable property located within a taxing districtâ€™s boundaries 
  by the districtâ€™s annual budget. [5] 
The effect of the Ordinance in tax year 2001 was 
  to reduce the fair market value of many owner-occupied residences.Â  As the result 
  of the Ordinanceâ€™s reduction of the total value of taxable real property in 
  the County, the millage rate for all taxing districts was higher than it would 
  have been had all property been fully valued.Â  All County taxpayers in 2001 
  were affected by the higher millage although taxpayers who benefited from the 
  Ordinanceâ€™s cap ultimately received a tax bill for an amount less than they 
  would have received had the cap not been imposed. The impact of the Ordinance 
  in tax year 2001 was to shift approximately $9.83 million of the tax burden 
  primarily to owners of non-owner-occupied primary residences.
Following the adoption of the Ordinance, but prior to the date 
  2001 property taxes were due, certain county taxpayers (Riverwoods plaintiffs) 
  brought an action challenging the legality of the Ordinance.Â  The Riverwoods 
  plaintiffs sought a declaratory judgment striking down the Ordinance and also 
  sought an injunction.Â  The trial judge found the Ordinance invalid, but declined 
  â€œto issue injunctive relief of any sort that would constitute affirmative judicial 
  interference with the Countyâ€™s taxing processesâ€¦Â  Whether the County chooses 
  on its own to take any remedial action in light of this Courtâ€™s decision is 
  up to it.â€Â  Riverwoods circuit court order.
County appealed the Riverwoods order to the extent it struck 
  down the Ordinance, and the Riverwoods plaintiffs cross-appealed the 
  denial of injunctive relief.Â  On appeal, the Court held the Ordinance invalid 
  because it violated the terms of the Enabling Act which did not permit the 15% 
  cap to be limited to owner-occupied primary residences.Â  Riverwoods, LLC 
  v. County of Charleston, 349 S.C. 378, 563 S.E.2d 651 (2002).Â  In affirming 
  the Riverwoods plaintiffsâ€™ appeal from the denial of the injunction, 
  we held that they had an adequate legal remedy in that they could pay their 
  2001 ad valorem property taxes â€œunder protestâ€ [6]  and cited S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-60-2550 (2000). [7] 
After the circuit court filed its order in Riverwoods striking 
  down the Ordinance, five taxpayers paid their 2001 real property taxes â€œunder 
  protestâ€ and virtually simultaneously filed a civil action seeking a declaratory 
  judgment that the Ordinance was invalid and seeking a refund.Â  This suit, and 
  ensuing cross-appeals, is resolved by our opinion in the companion case to the 
  present controversy.Â  See Hoefer Family Ltd. Partnership v. County 
  of Charleston, Op. No. 25856 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed August 16, 2004) (Shearouse 
  Adv. Sh. 32).
The Taxpayers in this case timely paid their 2001 real property taxes; 
  following our decision in Riverwoods declaring the Ordinance invalid, 
  they initiated this circuit court action seeking certification of a taxpayer 
  class and refunds for all class members.Â  The circuit court certified a class 
  and ordered refunds; in so doing, it refused Countyâ€™s request that the action 
  be dismissed in order for Taxpayers to exhaust their administrative remedies.Â  
  Both Taxpayers and County have appealed numerous issues.Â  We find it necessary 
  to address only the issue whether Taxpayers were required to exhaust their administrative 
  remedies rather than bring this direct refund suit in circuit court.
ISSUE

Was the circuit court obligated to dismiss this suit for 
  a refund because Taxpayers had failed to exhaust their administrative remedies?

ANALYSIS
In 1995 the General Assembly adopted the South Carolina 
  Revenue Procedures Act [8]  (the 
  Act) â€œto provide the people of this State with a straight forward procedure 
  to determine any disputed revenue liability.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-60-20 (2000). 
  [9] Â  Section 12-60-80 (Supp. 2003) of the Act provides: [10]  

Â§ 12-60-80.Â  Wrongful collection of taxes; declaratory judgment; class action 
  prohibited.
(A) Except as provided in subsection (B), there is no remedy other than those 
  provided in this chapter in any case involving the illegal or wrongful collection 
  of taxes, or attempt to collect taxes.
(emphasis supplied).
(B) Notwithstanding subsection (A), an action for a declaratory judgment where 
  the sole issue is whether a statute is constitutional may be brought in circuit 
  court.Â  This exception does not include a claim that the statute is unconstitutional 
  as applied to a person or a limited class or classes of persons.
(C) Notwithstanding subsections (A) and (B), a claim or action for the refund 
  of taxes may not be brought as a class action in the Administrative Law Judge 
  Division or any court of law in this State, and the department, political subdivisions, 
  or their instrumentalities may not be named or made a defendant in any other 
  class action brought in this State.

If a taxpayer brings a circuit 
  court action when she should have pursued administrative remedies under the 
  Act, the circuit court â€œshall dismiss the case without prejudice.â€Â  Â§ 12-60-3390 
  (2000 and Supp. 2003).Â  County contends the circuit court erred in refusing 
  to dismiss Taxpayersâ€™ direct refund suit without prejudice under this statute 
  since Taxpayers were required to first pursue administrative remedies under 
  the Act.Â  We agree.
The circuit court reviewed 
  our decision in Riverwoods, supra, which indicated that the remedy 
  for taxpayers aggrieved by the Ordinance was found in Â§ 12-60-2550.Â  The circuit 
  court held that Taxpayers were not obligated to pursue this administrative remedy 
  since their objection did not challenge their Property Tax Assessment (PTA), 
  which is the only type of property tax protest contemplated by this statute.Â  
  The circuit court went on to hold that Taxpayers had no remedy under the Act 
  because the court concluded that the Act did not provide a procedure for any 
  type of challenge other than to the PTA.Â  As explained below, we agree that 
  Â§ 12-60-2550 is not applicable to these Taxpayers, but conclude the circuit 
  court erred in concluding they had no administrative remedy under the Act. 
The Act contains detailed procedures for a taxpayer who wishes 
  to challenge the countyâ€™s determination of her propertyâ€™s PTA , that is, the 
  fair market value, the special use value, or the assessment ratio, the components 
  of the PTA.Â  Â§ 12-60-30(19).Â  Under the statutory scheme, most PTA appeals are 
  initiated and resolved well before the taxes are due.Â  The procedures found 
  in article 9 of the Act apply to all PTA appeals. Â§12-60-1710 (2000).Â  In years 
  where there has been a countywide reassessment, notice of the new valuations 
  must be mailed to property owners by February 1. [11] Â  Â§12-60-2510 (2000 and Supp. 2003).Â  In other years, the assessor 
  must give notice by July 1 to owners whose property values have been increased 
  by $1,000 or more.Â  Id.Â  The property owner has 30 
  [12]  days to give the assessor written notice if she objects to one or 
  more of the PTA components.Â  Â§ 12-60-2510(3).Â  A written request for a meeting 
  with the assessor is the equivalent of notice that the taxpayer objects to the 
  PTA.Â  Â§ 12-60-2520(A).Â  If, after reviewing the written objection, the assessor 
  agrees with the property owner, the assessor must correct the error.Â  Â§ 12-60-2520(B).Â  
  If she does not agree, then she must schedule a meeting.Â  If the issue is not 
  resolved at the meeting, then the assessor must give the taxpayer protest information.Â  
  Id.Â  On this protest form, the taxpayer must identify which part of the 
  PTA she disagrees with, that is the propertyâ€™s value or its classification, 
  and propose her suggested value or class.Â  Â§ 12-60-2520(B)(5).Â  The assessor 
  must respond to the protest within 30 days, and give the taxpayer notice that 
  she must pursue any appeal before the county board of assessment appeals.Â  Â§ 
  12-60-2520(B)(4).
The county board of 
  assessment appeals(board) â€œmay rule on any timely appeal relating to the correctness 
  of any of the elements of the [PTA]â€¦.â€Â  Â§ 12-60-2530.Â  After the boardâ€™s written 
  disposition of an appeal, the aggrieved party (whether taxpayer or assessor) 
  may appeal to the Administrative Law Judge Division.Â  Â§ 12-60-2540.Â  If the 
  PTA appeal will not be concluded by December 31 of the tax year, the assessor 
  must ask the auditor to issue an adjusted property tax bill figured on 80% of 
  the protested assessment.Â  Â§ 12-60-2550.
These statutes contemplate 
  that a PTA protest will be initiated prior to the payment of any tax, and anticipates 
  that most PTA protests will be resolved before the taxes are due.Â  In situations 
  where the PTA appeal will not be concluded by December 31, Â§ 12-60-2550 provides 
  for the issuance of a reduced bill and mandates a refund if the appeal results 
  in a decision that the Taxpayer owes an amount less than the 80% already paid.Â  
  Â§ 12-60-2550(C).
There may be situations where the PTA protest is initiated so close to the 
  tax due date that it is not possible for the auditor to issue an adjusted bill 
  as provided by Â§ 12-60-2550.Â  In those rare situations the taxpayer will be 
  required to pay the bill in full, and her remedy will be to initiate an administrative 
  refund action pursuant to Â§ 12-60-2560. 
  [13] 
While the Act contains many 
  specific procedures for taxpayers challenging their PTAs, relief under the Act 
  is not limited to these types of protests.Â  Section 12-60-2530(A) specifically 
  provides the board of assessment appeals may rule on any PTA dispute â€œand also 
  other relevant claims of a legal or factual nature except claims relating to 
  property tax exemptions.â€Â  Although no prepayment procedure is specified for 
  non-PTA protests, the Act does provide for a taxpayer to seek a refund of taxes 
  paid.Â  Â§ 12-60-2560 (2000).Â  The first part of this refund statute provides 
  that a person seeking a refund because of an alleged PTA error must comply with 
  the specific limitations found in Â§ 12-60-1750, which in turn refers to the 
  time limitations initiating PTA appeals.Â  Â§ 12-60-2560(A).Â  Subsection (A) of 
  the refund statute requires persons seeking administrative refunds for reasons 
  other than PTA errors to commence those actions within the time limits of Â§ 
  12-54-85(F), which is essentially a two-year statute of limitations.Â  If Â§ 12-60-2560 
  were limited to PTA refunds, as the circuit court found here, then there would 
  be no reason for it to refer to Â§ 12-54-85(F) since the time limits for commencing 
  all related actions would be the 90 day PTA limit found in Â§ 12-60-2510(3). 

As with PTA protests, a taxpayer commences a refund action by filing a claim 
  with the assessor.Â  Â§ 12-60-2560(A).Â  In refund actions, however, the assessor 
  together with the auditor and treasurer make the initial determination.Â  If 
  the refund request is denied, the taxpayer may appeal to the county board of 
  assessment appeals.Â  The refund statute contains a specific reference to the 
  boardâ€™s authority to rule on a timely PTA appeal, just as the PTA appellate 
  statute specifically refers to the boardâ€™s ability to rule on timely PTA appeals 
  as well as â€œother relevant claims of a legal or factual natureâ€¦â€Â  Compare 
  Â§ 12-60-2560(B) with Â§ 12-60-2530(B).Â  The refund statute then defaults 
  to the procedures followed by the board in a PTA appeal under Â§ 12-60-2530.Â  
  Â§ 12-60-2560(B-D) (2000).
A taxpayer disputing a PTA 
  must timely initiate his claim.Â  A timely PTA claim will, in almost all instances, 
  be made before any tax is due: if not resolved prior to that due date, then 
  a taxpayer may invoke the 80% payment procedure found in Â§ 12-60-2550.Â  In those 
  unusual circumstances where a PTA protest is not commenced prior to the tax 
  due date, and in all other circumstances where a taxpayer believes that he has 
  been wrongly or illegally required to pay a property tax, then the taxpayer 
  must first pay the tax and then initiate a request for a refund pursuant to 
  Â§ 12-60-2560.
These Taxpayers do not dispute any component of their PTA.Â  Rather, Taxpayers 
  complain that their PTA was subjected to a higher millage, and thus their tax 
  bills were inflated, as the consequence of the application of the unlawful Ordinance.Â  
  Looking first to the Act, as we must, 
  [14]  we hold that Taxpayersâ€™ remedy is not this direct circuit court refund 
  suit, but rather an administrative refund pursuant to Â§ 12-60-2560.Â  In fact, 
  Taxpayers acknowledged at oral argument that they had initiated an administrative 
  refund action, which has been stayed pending disposition of this appeal.Â  Since 
  Taxpayers had this administrative refund remedy available to them, the circuit 
  court erred in refusing to dismiss this action without prejudice.Â  Â§ 12-60-3390.Â  
  Accordingly, we reverse the circuit court orders and remand this matter with 
  instructions to dismiss the suit without prejudice to Taxpayersâ€™ rights to pursue 
  their refund requests.
We are deeply concerned that other taxpayers within the class certified by 
  the circuit court judge [15]  in this case may have forgone 
  their administrative remedies in reliance on the orders issued in this case.Â  
  For this reason, and because County concedes, as it must, that it is required 
  to return the unlawfully collected taxes, we instruct that all taxpayers within 
  the class who have not yet filed administrative refund actions shall have 120 
  days after the remittitur is sent to file such claims.Â  Notice of this right 
  shall be given to all eligible taxpayers, in writing, by County within thirty 
  days of the filing of this opinion.
Further, we express our 
  disapproval of Countyâ€™s actions in all matters related to this Ordinance.Â  County 
  chose, in the face of a court order striking down the Ordinance and a blunt 
  warning by the trial judge that it was proceeding at its own risk, to collect 
  taxes pursuant to that Ordinance.Â  Once the Ordinanceâ€™s invalidity was confirmed 
  by this Court, County chose not to refund the illegally collected taxes promptly, 
  but chose instead to place obstacles in the way of its wronged taxpayers.Â  County 
  did not promptly pay refunds to taxpayers who initiated a court action, nor, 
  the record shows, did it pay those taxpayers who pursued administrative remedies.Â  
  Instead of minimizing the fiscal impact of its unwise decision to levy taxes 
  in reliance on the Ordinance, County has expended more taxpayer money fighting 
  the refund-seekers on every front.
Further, in an unprecedented act, County audaciously suggested to the trial 
  judge, and now suggests to us, that the judicial system issue a writ of mandamus 
  to County requiring it to rebill all County taxpayers who benefited in 2001 
  from the unlawful Ordinance.Â  It is axiomatic that mandamus, â€œthe highest judicial 
  writ known to the law,â€ [16]  lies only to compel the performance of a ministerial act and 
  â€œis limitedâ€¦to the protection of a plain, admitted, and unquestioned legal right 
  that has been arbitrarily or without due warrant of law denied.â€Â  Gardner 
  v. Blackwell, 167 S.C. 313, 320, 166 S.E. 338, 340 (1932).Â  Were the duty 
  so clear that issuance of this prerogative writ was warranted, then County would 
  not need our imprimatur in order to act. [17] Â  
CONCLUSION
The circuit court orders are reversed and the 
  case remanded with instructions to the circuit court to dismiss the suit without 
  prejudice pursuant to Â§ 12-60-3390.Â  Further, County shall, within thirty days 
  of this opinion, give written notice to all taxpayers within the class certified 
  by the circuit court, other than those who have already initiated administrative 
  refund requests, of their right to seek an administrative refund, and of the 
  date by which the refund request must be initiated.Â  Finally, pursuant to Rule 
  222(a), SCACR, we award Taxpayers their appellate costs, and a reasonable attorneyâ€™s 
  fee.Â  Accordingly, the orders on appeal are
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
BURNETT, J., and Acting Justice J. Ernest Kinard, 
  Jr., concur.Â  MOORE, A.C.J., dissenting in a separate opinion in which WALLER, 
  J., concurs.

ACTING CHIEF JUSTICE MOORE:Â  The majorityâ€™s decision requires Taxpayers 
  to pursue administrative remedies by filing claims for refunds with the county 
  assessor under Â§ 12-60-2560.Â  I respectfully dissent. [18] Â 
As the majority points out, Taxpayersâ€™ claims do not involve property tax assessments 
  but instead challenge the proper millage rate to be applied in calculating the 
  amount of tax due.Â  The county assessor has no authority regarding millage rates 
  and relief under Â§ 12-60-2560 is inappropriate.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 
  12-37-90 (2000) (responsibilities and duties of assessors); see also 
  County of Lee v. Stevens, 277 S.C. 421, 289 S.E.2d 155 (1982) (the authority 
  to set the tax rate belongs to the county governing body).Â  
Further, Chapter 60, Subarticle 9, including Â§ 12-60-2560, applies only to 
  complaints regarding county property tax assessments.Â Â  Section 12-60-2560 provides 
  in pertinent part:

(A)Â  Subject to the limitations 
  in Section 12-60-1750, and within the time limitation of Section 12-54-85(F), 
  a property taxpayer may seek a refund of real property taxes assessed by the 
  county assessor and paid . . . by filing a claim for refund with the county 
  assessor. . . .

The majority concludes the 
  reference to the statute of limitation found in Â§ 12-54-85(F) indicates that 
  Â§ 12-60-2560 must allow appeals aside from property tax assessments since property 
  tax assessments are already governed by the time lines set out in Â§ 12-60-2510.Â  
  I disagree.Â  Refund claims under Â§ 12-60-2560 are governed by the general statute 
  of limitation in Â§ 12-54-85(F) because Â§ 12-60-2560 allows challenges to the 
  assessment ratio for prior years.Â  Other sections of the tax code specify that 
  Â§ 12-60-2560 is the remedy in this assessment context.Â  See S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 12-43-220(c)(3) (2000) (allowing application under Â§ 12-60-2560 
  for refund because the property was eligible for the legal residence assessment 
  ratio); see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-37-252(B) (2000) (â€œWhen a person 
  qualifies for a refund pursuant to Sections 12-60-2560 and 12-43-220(c) 
  for prior yearsâ€™ eligibility for the four percent owner-occupied residential 
  assessment ratio, the person also may be certified for a homesteadÂ  tax exemption. 
  . . .â€).Â  This limited reading of Â§ 12-60-2560 is consistent with the remaining 
  sections of Subarticle 9 which all relate to county property tax assessments. 

In sum, Chapter 60 does 
  not include contests to a countyâ€™s tax rate and the limitation in Â§ 12-60-80 
  to the remedies provided in this chapter does not control.Â  I therefore agree 
  with the circuit courtâ€™s ruling that the administrative process is limited to 
  challenges to an individualâ€™s property tax assessment and does not apply here.Â  

Further, the majorityâ€™s 
  decision allows those who benefited from the illegal ordinance to retain a windfall.Â  
  Since County has represented to this Court that it is willing to issue recalculated 
  tax bills to all taxpayers for the 2001 tax year, I would order it to do so.Â  
  This is a fair resolution to ensure that all taxpayers equitably share the tax 
  burden for services provided in 2001.Â  If County simply pays refunds, the amount 
  refunded must be included as a liability in a future budget.Â  It is unfair that 
  Taxpayers would then be taxed to cover the cost of their own refunds.
I would affirm. 
 WALLER, concurs.

 
   [1]  Appellants/Respondents in this appeal are the 
    County and three county officials: the treasurer, the auditor, and the assessor.Â  
    We will refer to them collectively as â€œCountyâ€ in this opinion.

 
   [2]  Property classified as owner-occupied primary 
    residences is taxed on an assessment equal to four percent of the fair market 
    value of the property.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-43-220(C)(1) (Supp. 2003).Â  All 
    other real property not specifically classified under section 12-43-220 is 
    taxed at six percent.Â  

 
   [3]  Different property within the County is subject 
    to different taxing entities depending on the propertyâ€™s location within, 
    for example, a municipality, and/or a special purpose district.

 
   [4]  County has adopted a Local Options Sales Tax (LOST).Â  See 
    S.C. Code Ann Â§Â§ 4-10-10 through -90 (Supp. 2003).Â  Pursuant to the LOST act, 
    each year a credit factor is determined for each taxing district within the 
    County; each parcelâ€™s individual credit is determined by multiplying the propertyâ€™s 
    fair market or special use value by the taxing entityâ€™s credit factor.Â  The 
    resulting credit is then subtracted from the tax assessment figure, resulting 
    in the actual tax owed by the property owner. 

 
   [5]  See also County of Lee v. Stevens, 
    277 S.C. 421, 289 S.E.2d 155 (1982) (explanation of ad valorem real 
    property tax system).

 
   [6]  Reference to â€œpaying under protestâ€ is an anachronism; 
    under the current tax scheme in Title 12, Chapter 60, there is no requirement 
    that an ad valorem taxpayer pay â€œunder protestâ€ in order to pursue 
    a refund.

 
   [7]  We incorrectly suggested that the Riverwoods 
    plaintiffs could seek prepayment relief under Â§ 12-60-2550, a statute concerned 
    only with PTA protests.

 
   [8]  1995 Act No. 60.

 
   [9]  In 2000, the General Assembly substituted the 
    phrase â€œdispute with the Department of Revenueâ€ for â€œany disputed liabilityâ€ 
    in Â§ 12-60-20.Â  See Â§ 12-60-20 (Supp. 2003).Â  Although this amendment 
    could be read as indicative of an intent to limit the Act to tax issues involving 
    the DOR, when amending Â§ 12-60-20 the legislature did not amend or repeal 
    those parts of the Act which deal solely with county tax disputes.Â  In light 
    of this, we hold that a court must look first to the Act when faced with a 
    question of county tax protest procedures. Glover v. Suitt Constr. Co., 
    318 S.C. 465, 458 S.E.2d 535 (1995) (statutes which are part of the same general 
    law are construed together).

 
   [10]  This statute was amended effective June 18, 
    2003, prior to the final order in this matter.Â  Before that date, Â§ 12-60-80 
    read:
  
  There is no remedy other than those provided in this 
    chapter in any case involving the illegal or wrongful collection of taxes, 
    or attempt to collect taxes.
  
  The amendment does not affect our resolution of the 
    administrative remedies issue.

 
   [11]  Beginning in 2002, this date has been changed 
    to October 1.Â  2002 Act No. 271, Â§ 1.

 
   [12]  Now 90.

 
   [13]  See also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-43-220(C)(3) 
    (2000) (permitting refund action under Â§ 12-60-2560 notwithstanding any other 
    provision of law where property was eligible for a 4% classification).

 
   [14]  See Â§ 12-60-20 and Â§ 12-60-80.

 
   [15]  â€œAll real property taxpayers whom Charleston 
    County billed for 2001 ad valorem real property taxes and who owned 
    at least one parcel of real property subject to ad valorem taxes that 
    did not qualify for the value exemption under the tax cap Ordinance.â€

 
    [16]    Willimon v. City of Greenville, 243 S.C. 
    82, 86, 132 S.E.2d 169, 170 (1963).

 
   [17]  In 1903, we held that assessments for back taxes 
    could be made only â€œin pursuance of express and very specific statutory direction.â€Â  
    Milster v. City of Spartanburg, 68 S.C. 26, 32, 46 S.E. 539, 541 (1903).Â  
    We have been unable to locate statutory authority for a rebill of selected 
    taxpayers, nor have we been able to discern a ministerial duty on the part 
    of County to rebill certain taxpayers.Â  Compare S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-4-510 
    (3) (2000); see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-60-1740 (2000) (if funds are 
    not available for refunds, the county government must provide for repayment).

 
   [18] I 
    agree we incorrectly instructed the Riverwoods plaintiffs to apply 
    for administrative relief under Â§ 12-60-2550.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Charlotte Latimer, Stuart Latimer, and Michelle Farmer,       
Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Daniel Farmer,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Pickens County
Wayne M. Creech, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 25857
Heard May 27, 2004Â  - Filed August 16, 
  2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Raymond W. Godwin, of Greenville, for Appellants.
        Robert M. Rosenfeld, of Porter 
          & Rosenfeld, of Greenville, for Respondent.
Kelvin R. Kearse, of Easley, Guardian ad
Litem.
      
    
  

JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  This is a custody dispute arising 
  out of the custodial parentâ€™s relocation.Â  Appellant Michelle Latimer Farmer 
  (Mother) appeals the family court order concluding Respondent Daniel W. Farmer 
  (Father) should be allowed to relocate with their adopted child (Child).Â  Appellants 
  Charlotte and Stuart Latimer (Grandparents) appeal the family courtâ€™s order 
  denying them autonomous visitation rights with Child.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Mother and Father were married on June 4, 1988 and 
  were divorced on February 11, 2000 because of Motherâ€™s adultery with one John 
  Case.Â  
Approximately a year and a half before the divorce, Father 
  and Mother adopted Child, a Romanian orphan born May 14, 1997.Â  Father and Mother 
  brought Child home to Greenville in August 1998.Â  Three weeks later, Father 
  discovered Motherâ€™s adulterous relationship with Case.Â  Mother agreed to terminate 
  the relationship and the couple were reconciled.
In May 1999, the partiesâ€™ adoption of Child was completed.Â  
  One month later, Mother separated from Father.Â  Father became suspicious of 
  Motherâ€™s activities, and, at the suggestion of Motherâ€™s parents, hired a private 
  investigator who confirmed Mother was still involved in the adulterous relationship.Â  
  Following initiation of divorce proceedings by Father, the parties, by agreement, 
  resolved all issues incident to the divorce.Â  The agreement provided Father 
  would have sole custody of Child and Mother was given visitation each week from 
  6:00 p.m. Thursday through 6:00 p.m. Saturday and additional visitation during 
  holiday and vacation periods. 
Father is an automation programmer. [1] Â  While in Greenville Father was employed by 
  Fluor-Daniel Corporation.Â  Father sought and received a job offer in Plymouth, 
  Michigan and now resides there with Child, his new wife, and a child born to 
  them.Â  
When Father informed Mother he was moving to Michigan, Mother and Grandparents 
  sought and obtained an ex parte order preventing Father from moving to 
  Michigan with Child.Â  Appellants also sought a permanent restraining order preventing 
  Father from moving out of state with Child or, in the alternative, transfer 
  of custody to Mother.Â Â  A hearing was held in November 2001.Â  The court concluded 
  it to be in Childâ€™s best interests to allow Father to move to Michigan with 
  Child.Â  The court also denied Grandparentsâ€™ autonomous visitation rights independent 
  of those of Mother.Â  The court ordered extensive visitation for Mother, including 
  computer teleconferencing, e-mail, and telephone contact. 
  [2] Â  
ISSUES

I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Did the family court err in allowing Father to relocate to Michigan 
  and declining to change custody of Child to Mother?
II.Â  Â Â Â  Did the Guardian ad Litem (GAL) adhere to 
  the proper standards in conducting his investigation?
  III.     Did the family court judge abuse his discretion in denying separate visitation 
  rights to Grandparents?

LAW/ANALYSIS
Where a family court order is appealed, we have jurisdiction 
  to find facts based on our own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  We 
  are not required to disregard the findings of the trial judge who saw and heard 
  the witnesses and was in a better position to evaluate their credibility.Â  Strout 
  v. Strout, 284 S.C. 429, 327 S.E.2d 74 (1985).Â  This degree of deference 
  is especially true in cases involving the welfare and best interests of the 
  child.Â  Dixon v. Dixon, 336 S.C. 260, 263, 519 S.E.2d 357, 359 (Ct. App. 
  1999).Â Â  Our broad scope of review does not relieve the appealing party of the 
  burden of showing the family court committed error.Â  Skinner v. King, 
  272 S.C. 520, 252 S.E.2d 891 (1979).
I.
We are called upon to resolve one of the most challenging 
  problems our family courts encounter.Â  Cases involving the relocation of a custodial 
  parent with a minor child bring into direct conflict a custodial parentâ€™s freedom 
  to move to another state without permission from the court and the noncustodial 
  parentâ€™s right to continue his or her relationship with the child as established 
  before the custodial parentâ€™s relocation.Â Â  
Some states recognize a presumption in favor of the custodial 
  parentâ€™s right to relocate.Â  See e.g., In re Custody of D.M.G. 
  & T.J.G., 951 P.2d 1377, 1383 (Mont. 1998); In re Marriage of Burgess, 
  13 Cal.4th 25 (1996).Â  Since our decision in McAlister v. Patterson, 
  278 S.C. 481, 299 S.E.2d 322 (1982), the courts in this state have been guided 
  by a presumption against relocation in determining whether to allow a custodial 
  parent to relocate with a minor child.Â  We take this opportunity to review this 
  presumption.Â  Insofar as McAlister established a presumption against 
  relocation, we hereby overrule it for the following reasons.Â  
First, we recognize that standards imposing restrictions 
  on relocation have become antiquated in our increasingly transient society.Â  
  Second, confusion abounds surrounding the status of our relocation law, in part, 
  because of the often stated, but infrequently applied, presumption against relocation.Â  
  In all child custody cases, including relocation cases, the controlling considerations 
  are the childâ€™s welfare and best interests.Â  The presumption against relocation 
  is a meaningless supposition to the extent a custodial parentâ€™s relocation would, 
  in fact, be in the childâ€™s best interest.
Under the present facts, Mother seeks a change in custody.Â  
  As in all matters of child custody, a change in custody analysis inevitably 
  asks whether the transfer in custody is in the childâ€™s best interests.Â  In order 
  for a court to grant a change in custody, there must be a showing of changed 
  circumstances occurring subsequent to the entry of the divorce decree.Â  Davenport 
  v. Davenport, 265 S.C. 524, 220 S.E.2d 228 (1975).Â  â€œA change in circumstances 
  justifying a change in the custody of a child simply means that sufficient facts 
  have been shown to warrant the conclusion that the best interests of the children 
  would be served by the change.â€Â  Stutz v. Funderburk, 272 S.C. 273, 276, 
  252 S.E.2d 32, 34 (1979).Â Â  The change of circumstances relied on for a change 
  of custody must be such as would substantially affect the interest and welfare 
  of the child.Â  Because the best interest of the child is the overriding concern 
  in all child custody matters, when a non-custodial parent seeks a change in 
  custody, the non-custodial parent must establish the following: (1) there has 
  been a substantial change in circumstances affecting the welfare of the child 
  and (2) a change in custody is in the overall best interests of the child.Â  

In the present case, Mother seeks a change in custody.Â  
  Therefore, she bears the burden of establishing both of these criteria. [3] 
Mother has failed to show a substantial change 
  in circumstances warranting a change in custody from Father to Mother for reasons 
  set forth below.Â Â  Fatherâ€™s remarriage, in and of itself, is not a sufficient 
  change of circumstance affecting the welfare of Child to warrant a transfer 
  of custody to Mother.Â  See Fisher v. Miller, 288 S.C. 576, 344 
  S.E.2d 149 (1986) (remarriage alone is not sufficient to warrant a change in 
  custody).Â  Likewise, a change in Fatherâ€™s residence is not itself a substantial 
  change in circumstances affecting the welfare of Child, which justifies a change 
  in custody.Â  We decline to hold relocation in itself is a substantial change 
  in circumstance affecting the welfare of a child.Â  Relocation is one factor 
  in considering a change in circumstances, but is not alone a sufficient change 
  in circumstances.Â  One location may not necessarily affect the best interests 
  of the child as would another.Â  The effect of relocation on the childâ€™s best 
  interest is highly fact specific.Â  It should not be assumed that merely relocating 
  and potentially burdening the non-custodial parentâ€™s visitation rights always 
  negatively affects the childâ€™s best interests.Â  
 Not only has Mother failed to show a 
  change in circumstances affecting Childâ€™s welfare, she has also failed to show 
  a change in custody would be in Childâ€™s best interests.Â  We believe the best 
  interests of Child are served by Fatherâ€™s relocation with Child to Michigan.Â  
  We have not previously delineated criteria for evaluating whether the best interests 
  of the child are served in relocation cases.Â  As noted by the Court of Appeals 
  in Pitt v. Olds, 327 S.C. 512, 519, 489 S.E.2d 666, 670 (Ct. App. 1997), 
  reversed on other grounds, 333 S.C. 478, 511 S.E.2d 60 (1999), other 
  states have provided criteria to guide a courtâ€™s decision.Â  We do not endorse 
  or specifically approve any of these factors for consideration, but merely provide 
  the following for consideration in determining whether a childâ€™s best interests 
  are served.Â  For example, the New York Court of Appeal has set forth the following 
  factors when determining if the childâ€™s best interests are served:

  (1)     each parentâ€™s reasons for seeking or opposing 
  the move,
  (2)     the quality of the relationships between the child 
  and the custodial and noncustodial parents,
  (3)     the impact of the move on the quality of the childâ€™s 
  future contact with the noncustodial parent, 
  (4)     the degree to which the custodial parentâ€™s and 
  childâ€™s life may be enhanced economically, emotionally, and educationally by 
  the move, and
  (5)     the feasibility of preserving the relationship 
  between the noncustodial parent and child through suitable visitation arrangements.

Tropea v. Tropea, 665 N.E.2d 145, 148 (N.Y. 1996). 
Â Pennsylvania requires courts in potential relocation cases to
consider: 

  (1)       the potential advantages of the proposed 
  move,Â economic or otherwise;Â  
  (2)       the likelihood the move would improve 
  substantially the quality of life for the custodial parent and the children 
  and is not the result of a whim on the part of the custodial parent;
  (3)       the integrity of the motives of both 
  the custodial and noncustodial parent in seeking the move or seeking to prevent 
  it;
  (4)       and the availability of realistic 
  substitute visitation arrangements that will adequately foster an ongoing relationship 
  between the child and the noncustodial parent.

Gancas v. Schultz, 683 A.2d 1207, 1210 (Pa. Super. Ct. 1996).Â Â Â  
Montana and Florida have compiled comparable factors. [4] 
Applying some of these factors to this case and considering 
  foremost the overriding consideration in all custody matters, i.e., the 
  best interests of the child, we affirm the family courtâ€™s order allowing Father 
  to relocate to Michigan and denying a change in custody.Â  
First, the potential advantages of the proposed 
  move weigh in favor of Fatherâ€™s relocation.Â  Fatherâ€™s current job, unlike his 
  previous employment in Greenville, does not require travel, thereby allowing 
  him to spend more time with Child.Â  Additionally, Father has a stable family 
  environment in Michigan having his siblings in close vicinity.Â  Mother and her 
  family, on the other hand, have a history of familial discord.Â  Not only has 
  Motherâ€™s relationship with her parents been unstable, Motherâ€™s brother is currently 
  estranged from Grandparents.Â  
Childâ€™s moral upbringing is also enhanced by her relocation with 
  Father.Â  The family court concluded even though Mother was a full time homemaker 
  prior to the partiesâ€™ separation, Father assumed the majority of the care of 
  Child when he came home from work.Â  The court also found Father has taken the 
  responsibility for the moral upbringing of Child by taking her to church and 
  reading her Bible stories.Â  
Second, we conclude it likely the move would improve the quality 
  of life for the custodial parent and the child, and it is not the result of 
  a whim on the part of the custodial parent.Â  For the reasons stated above, the 
  quality of Childâ€™s life would be enhanced by the dependable and loving family 
  environment in Michigan.Â  
Third, the integrity of the motives of both the custodial and noncustodial 
  parent in seeking the move or seeking to prevent it neither weigh in favor of 
  nor against Childâ€™s best interests.Â  The family court concluded Fatherâ€™s primary 
  reason for the move was job related.Â  Neither Fatherâ€™s reasons for moving nor 
  Motherâ€™s reasons for seeking a change in custody seem to originate from spiteful 
  or vindictive motives thereby affecting Childâ€™s best interests.
Fourth, we 
  consider the availability of a realistic substitute visitation arrangement that 
  will adequately foster an ongoing relationship between Mother and Child.Â  Clearly, 
  the relationship between Mother and Child will be significantly affected given 
  the prior frequency of contact and the hardship now imposed on the visitation 
  schedule because of the distance to travel.Â  Mother is provided extensive contact 
  with Child given the distance involved.Â  As previously noted, the family court 
  ordered Mother would have extensive visitation with Child.Â  
Mother raises several evidentiary issues in disputing the 
  family courtâ€™s order that Childâ€™s relocation with Father is in Childâ€™s best 
  interests.Â  First, Mother argues the family court erred in allowing testimony 
  about her adulterous conduct predating the adoption hearing, which violated 
  principles of res judicata.Â  We disagree.Â  Res judicata requires three elements: 
  (1) the judgment must be final, valid and on the merits; (2) the parties in 
  the subsequent action must be identical in the first; (3) the second action 
  must involve matters properly included in the first action.Â  Plum Creek Dev. 
  Co., Inc. v. City of Conway, 334 S.C. 30, 512 S.E.2d 106 (1999).Â  The third 
  element is not satisfied.Â  The courtâ€™s finding in the adoption hearing on the 
  fitness of parents for purposes of adoption has no bearing on any future determination 
  of custody.Â  
As to Motherâ€™s assertion the family court judge overemphasized 
  Motherâ€™s adultery in refusing to transfer custody to her, a review of the order 
  shows this determination was not based on Wifeâ€™s adulterous conduct. The family 
  court made specific findings regarding the best interests of Child and the effect 
  of her relocation on her welfare.Â  Specifically, the court found Father has 
  taken a proactive role in Childâ€™s life, has taken responsibility for Childâ€™s 
  moral upbringing, and has a history of fostering familial relationships.Â  It 
  is upon these bases the family court judge made his determination regarding 
  custody.Â  Even with no proof of adultery, the record supports the grant of custody 
  to Father.
Second, Mother argues the court failed to give due consideration 
  to Childâ€™s age and background in determining whether a change in custody was 
  appropriate. We disagree.Â  The court did consider Childâ€™s age and the fact Child 
  is a Romanian orphan and Mother previously had significant visitation.Â  Recognizing 
  the hardship imposed on the mother/daughter relationship, the Court made a special 
  provision for â€œliveâ€ video teleconferencing.Â  Additionally, Father actively 
  participated in the Romanian adoption and there is no indication Mother has 
  special knowledge regarding Romanian orphans.Â  
Finally, Mother contends the court improperly ignored the 
  testimony of Heather Cirelli, an expert who spoke on the possible negative consequences 
  of Father relocating with Child.Â  We disagree.Â  In the courtâ€™s Order on Motion 
  to Reconsider, the court expressed great reservation about Cirelliâ€™s credentials.Â  
  The court stated it exercised great latitude in even qualifying Cirelli as an 
  expert.Â  Cirelli was contacted about three weeks prior to trial and saw Child 
  only once.Â  To the extent Mother advanced a contrary opinion at trial, the family 
  court acted within its discretion in assigning more weight to Fatherâ€™s expert.Â  
  See Bragg v. Bragg, 347 S.C. 16, 21-22, 553 S.E.2d 251, 254 (Ct. 
  App. 2001) (appellate court is not required to ignore the trial judge who saw 
  and heard the witnesses and was in a better position to evaluate their credibility 
  and assign comparative weight to their testimony).
For the foregoing reasons, Mother has failed to show (1) 
  a substantial change in circumstances affecting Childâ€™s welfare and (2) a change 
  in custody advances Childâ€™s overall best interests.Â  Additionally, the court 
  did not err in its evidentiary rulings. 
II.
Mother argues the trial court erred in failing to require 
  the GAL to adhere to the standards we set forth in Patel v. Patel, 347 
  S.C. 281, 555 S.E.2d 386 (2001).Â Â  The present case was filed in April 2000 
  and pre-dates the Patel opinion.Â  Although the GAL was allowed to make 
  a recommendation regarding custody prior to the Patel decision, we conclude 
  the guardian meticulously conducted an independent, balanced, and impartial 
  investigation.Â  
In Patel, we set the baseline standards for the responsibilities 
  and duties of a GAL.Â  In particular, the GAL shall:

conduct an independent, balanced, and impartial investigation to determine 
  the facts relevant to the situation of the child and the family, which should 
  include:Â  reviewing relevant documents; meeting with and observing the child 
  in the home setting and considering the childâ€™s wishes, if appropriate; and 
  interviewing parents, caregivers, and others with knowledge relevant to the 
  case.

Id. at 288, 555 S.E.2d at 390; see also South Carolina 
  Private Guardian Ad Litem Reform Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1549 (Supp. 2003) 
  (codifying the Patel guidelines with more specificity, but only directly 
  applicable to guardians ad litem appointed after January 15, 2003).
In Patel, the GALâ€™s investigation overwhelmingly 
  favored the husband.Â  For example, the GAL contacted the husbandâ€™s attorney 
  nineteen times, but failed to ever contact wifeâ€™s counsel.Â  The GAL only met 
  with the children when they were with the husband.Â  The GAL even secretly listened 
  in on conversations between husband and wife while visiting with the husband.Â  
  Id. at 286, 555 S.E.2d at 388-89. Â The Court concluded the actions and 
  inactions of the GAL so tainted the decision of the family court that wife was 
  not afforded due process.Â  Id. at 286-87, 291, 555 S.E.2d at 389, 391.
In this case the GAL submitted two reports. The GAL 
  interviewed Mother on several occasions and observed Mother and Child together 
  on one occasion.Â  The GAL also met independently with Motherâ€™s new husband.Â  
  When the GAL learned Mother had remarried, the GAL requested Mother send photographs 
  of her new home and Childâ€™s bedroom.Â  The GAL noted the Motherâ€™s residence was 
  â€œvery adequate.â€Â  The GAL also stated that if Child were placed with Mother 
  and her husband on a permanent basis, Child would not suffer.Â  The GAL testified 
  Mother did a good job with Child, takes good care of her and her husband seemed 
  â€œvery genteel.â€Â  
The GAL observed 
  Father with Child on two occasions.Â  One visit was at the former marital home 
  in Easley and the other was in the GALâ€™s office.Â  The GAL did not visit the 
  Father in Michigan, finding it would present an undue financial burden for the 
  litigants.Â  Instead, the GAL requested Father send information pertaining to 
  the town where Father was living, the schools, and pictures of the home.Â  Therefore, 
  there is no merit to Motherâ€™s assertion that the GAL was biased because he asked 
  Father to prepare an album for him with information about Fatherâ€™s situation. 

Finally, Mother 
  alleges the GAL has not spent substantial time with Child in eighteen months.Â  
  To the contrary, the GAL consistently inquired of both parents as to Childâ€™s 
  situation.Â  The GAL filed a supplemental report in July 2003.Â  The GAL attended 
  depositions of Mother and Father about six weeks prior to the trial date.Â  At 
  that time the GAL asked questions and received updated information.Â  We conclude 
  the GAL showed no bias or prejudice in the investigation. 

III.
Grandparents 
  argue the trial court erred in failing to permit them some form of autonomous 
  visitation with Child.Â  We disagree.
South Carolina 
  Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(33) (Supp. 2003) provides the family court has exclusive 
  jurisdiction 

to order periods of visitation for the grandparents of a 
  minor child where . . . parents of . . . child . . . are divorced . . . regardless 
  of the existence of a court order or agreement, and upon a written finding that 
  the visitation rights would be in the best interests of the child and would 
  not interfere with the parent/child relationship.Â  In determining whether to 
  order visitation for the grandparents, the court shall consider the nature of 
  the relationship between the child and his grandparents prior to the filing 
  of the petition or complaint.

In Brown v. Earnhardt, 302 S.C. 374, 396 S.E.2d 358 (1990), we stated,

it would seldom, if ever be in the best interests of the 
  child to grant visitation rights to the grandparents when their child, the parent, has 
  such rights.Â  Visitation by grandparents should be derivative; otherwise the 
  child might have four, or even six people competing for his company: father, 
  mother, paternal grandparents and maternal grandparents. 

Id. at 377, 396 S.E.2d at 360 (quoting In the Matter of Adoption 
  of a Child by M., 355 A.2d 211, 213 (N.J. Super. Ct. Ch. Div. 1976)).
In Camburn v. Smith, 355 S.C. 574, 586 S.E.2d 565 
  (2003), we applied the United State Supreme Courtâ€™s opinion in Troxel v. 
  Granville, 530 U.S. 57, 120 S.Ct. 2054, 147 L.Ed.2d 49 (2000).Â  Under Troxel, 
  the court must give â€œspecial weightâ€ to a fit parentâ€™s decision regarding visitation.Â  
  Before visitation may be awarded to grandparents over a parentâ€™s objection, 
  one of two evidentiary hurdles must be met:Â  the parent must be shown to be 
  unfit by clear and convincing evidence, or there must be evidence of compelling 
  circumstances to overcome the presumption that the parental decision is in the 
  childâ€™s best interest.
No compelling 
  or exceptional circumstances exist in this case that would warrant autonomous 
  visitation.Â  This is a difficult case because Grandparents enjoyed a close relationship 
  with Child and were her primary caretakers during the marital difficulties between 
  Mother and Father.Â  However, given the tumultuous nature of the relationship 
  between Mother and Grandparents, we believe autonomous visitation with Grandparents 
  could divide the family further should Motherâ€™s relationship with her parents 
  again deteriorate.Â  A contentious environment created by an additional visitation 
  schedule would not be in Childâ€™s best interests.Â  However, we strongly encourage 
  Mother to foster an ongoing relationship between Child and Grandparents by sharing 
  her visitation time with Grandparents when Child visits her in South Carolina.
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing 
  reasons, we affirm the decision of the family court (1) denying a change in 
  custody to Mother, (2) concluding the GAL followed appropriate standards in 
  his investigation, and (3) denying Grandparents autonomous visitation rights.
MOORE, A.C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice Clifton 
  Newman, concur.

 
   [1] While in Greenville, 
    Fatherâ€™s job entailed creating programs for automated industries, visiting 
    factories for which the programs were designed and implementing the programs.Â  
    He has no formal education, but has received on the job training.

 
   [2] Telephone contact 
    is unlimited when initiated by Child.Â  Wife has two calls per week not to 
    exceed thirty minutes at specified times.Â  Computer teleconferencing is unlimited 
    when initiated by Child and one per week when initiated by Wife.Â  E-mail access 
    is unlimited.

 
   [3] Mother disagrees that she bears 
    the burden of showing a substantial change in circumstances.Â  Mother argues 
    Father seeks to modify the custody agreement.Â  However, the custody agreement 
    is silent on whether Father could move out of state with Child.Â  Therefore, 
    there was no agreement on relocation to be modified.Â  This case is distinguishable 
    from Pitt v. Olds, 333 S.C. 478, 511 S.E.2d 60 (1999).Â  In Pitt, 
    the custodial, relocating parent sought a modification of the custody order 
    to alter the visitation schedule and consequently bore the burden of showing 
    a substantial change in circumstances.Â  In the present case, the non-custodial 
    parent seeks a change in custody and therefore bears the burden of showing 
    sufficient changed circumstances affecting the welfare of the child.

 
  Â  [4] 
    Montanaâ€™s factors are:
  
  (1) whether the prospective advantage of the move will 
    improve the general quality of life for parent and child; (2) the integrity 
    of the custodial parentâ€™s motives in moving; (3) the integrity of the noncustodial 
    parentâ€™s motives for opposing the relocation, and the extent to which it is 
    intended to secure a financial advantage with respect to continuing child 
    support and; (4) the realistic opportunity for visitation which can provide 
    an adequate basis for preserving and fostering the noncustodial parentâ€™s relationship 
    with the child if relocation is permitted.
  
  Carter v. Schilb, 877 S.W.2d 665, 667-68 (Mont. 
    Ct. App. 1994).
  Florida law provides the court must consider:
  
  (1) whether the move would be likely to improve the 
    general quality of life for both the residential parent and the child; (2) 
    the extent to which visitation rights have been allowed and exercised; (3) 
    whether the primary residential parent, once out of the jurisdiction, will 
    be likely to comply with any substitute visitation arrangements; (4) whether 
    the substitute visitation will be adequate to foster a continuing meaningful 
    relationship between the child and the secondary residential parent; (5) whether 
    the cost of transportation is financially affordable by one or both parties; 
    and (6) whether the move is in the best interests of the child.
  
  Florida Statutes Â§ 61.3(2)(d) (1997).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Benjamin Harden,       
Petitioner,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
State of South Carolina,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Richland County
L. Casey Manning, Post-Conviction Judge

Opinion No. 25858
Submitted January 22, 2004 - Filed August 
  16, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Tara Shurling, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, 
  Donald J. Zelenka, Chief, Capital and Collateral Litigation, Assistant Deputy 
  Attorney General B. Allen Bullard, and Assistant Attorney General David Spencer, 
  all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  We granted certiorari to review 
  the denial of Benjamin Hardenâ€™s (Petitionerâ€™s) second application for post-conviction 
  relief (PCR).Â  We granted Petitionerâ€™s first application for PCR, which was 
  denied after a hearing, and dismissed his petition for failure of counsel to 
  perfect the appeal.Â  Petitionerâ€™s motion to reinstate the appeal was denied.
Petitionerâ€™s second PCR application seeks review, pursuant 
  to Austin v. State, 305 S.C. 453, 409 S.E.2d 395 (1991), of the denial 
  of his PCR application.Â  The PCR judge found Petitioner was entitled to belated 
  review of the denial of his first PCR application.Â  Given the unique circumstances 
  presented, we granted certiorari and directed Petitioner to address the question 
  on which this Court originally granted certiorari.
FACTUAL BACKGROUND
Petitioner was indicted for one count 
  of trafficking crack cocaine by conspiracy between April 1, 1997, and September 
  23, 1997, in violation of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-375(C)(3) (2002) and four counts 
  of distribution of crack cocaine, in violation of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-375(B)(1) 
  (2002).Â  Each count of distribution occurred between April 1, 1997, and September 
  23, 1997.Â  On each occasion Petitioner sold crack cocaine to undercover agents 
  or witnesses.Â  On January 5, 1998, Petitioner pled guilty to trafficking and 
  to four counts of distribution.Â  The trial judge sentenced Petitioner to twenty 
  years for trafficking and concurrent fifteen-year sentences for each count of 
  distribution.
ISSUE

Was plea counsel ineffective for failing to object to and 
  advise Petitioner his convictions for both trafficking crack cocaine based on 
  conspiracy and the four distribution charges would violate double jeopardy?

ANALYSIS
Petitioner argues his convictions violate 
  double jeopardy principles because all of the distribution counts occurred during 
  the period encompassed by the trafficking indictment.Â  He argues PCR counsel 
  was ineffective in failing to raise the issue.Â  We disagree.
A defendant who pleads guilty on the 
  advice of counsel may only attack the voluntary and intelligent character of 
  the plea by showing (1) counselâ€™s representation fell below an objective standard 
  of reasonableness and (2) there is a reasonable probability that, but for, counselâ€™s 
  errors, the defendant would not have pled guilty, but would have gone to trial.Â  
  Hill v. Lockhart, 474 U.S. 52, 56-57, 106 S.Ct. 366, 369, 88 L.Ed.2d 
  203, 208 (1985);Â  McCray v. State, 317 S.C. 557, 455 S.E.2d 686 (1995).Â  
  Petitioner bears the burden of proving both attorney error and prejudice.Â  Strickland 
  v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668, 104 S.Ct. 2052, 80 L.Ed.2d 674 (1984).
There is no statutory law or judicial 
  precedent in this State which holds a conviction for both conspiracy and the 
  substantive offense relating to the conspiracy, in violation of the trafficking 
  statute, constitutes double jeopardy.Â  An attorney is not required to anticipate 
  potential changes in the law which are not in existence at the time of the conviction.Â  
  State v. Gilmore, 314 S.C. 453, 457, 445 S.E.2d 454, 456 (1994) overruled 
  on other grounds by Brightman v. State, 336 S.C. 348, 520 S.E.2d 
  614 (1999).Â  Therefore, Petitionerâ€™s counsel was not deficient in failing to 
  advise Petitioner or object to Petitionerâ€™s sentencing on the double jeopardy 
  issue.Â  
Petitioner relies on Matthews v. State, 300 S.C. 238, 387 
  S.E.2d 258 (1990).Â  In Matthews, we concluded possession with intent 
  to distribute marijuana is a lesser included offense of trafficking in marijuana 
  when the trafficking charge is based on possession.Â  Therefore, we held a defendant 
  may not be convicted of both possession with intent to distribute and trafficking 
  based on possession.Â  Where possession of an identical amount of marijuana would 
  sustain convictions for both possession with intent to distribute and trafficking 
  based upon possession, the General Assembly did not intend to permit punishment 
  under both statutory provisions. [1] 
  Â  
The present case is distinguishable.Â  In Matthews, 
  the convictions at issue were based on a single act of possession.Â  A review 
  of the record shows that in this case the trafficking conviction was based on 
  a broader conspiracy than the individual transactions which supported the distribution 
  charges.Â  
When examining issues related to a guilty plea, it is appropriate 
  to consider the entire record, including the transcript of the guilty plea, 
  and the evidence presented at the PCR hearing.Â  Anderson v. State, 342 
  S.C. 54, 535 S.E.2d 649 (2000).Â  The solicitorâ€™s comments at the plea hearing 
  demonstrate the factual circumstances of this case are unlike those in Matthews.Â  
  At the plea hearing, the solicitor stated the distribution indictments were 
  all based on audio-taped drug transactions.Â  Regarding the trafficking indictment, 
  however, the solicitor stated:

[T]his is a hardened drug family or drug network run by 
[Petitioner] . . . . [F]or at least the last six or seven 
  years [Petitioner] and his family have been probably the most dangerous and biggest nuisance that Richland County has had.Â  [Petitioner] 
  had no less than eight to ten people that worked directly with him . . . He had a number of trailers where he would sell 
  crack cocaine out of.Â  They set up a videotape on [March 10, 1997] and it worked 
  for 29 days . . . during the daylight hours . . . and over 424 visits were made 
  to that one trailer alone that were drug related . . .We have audiotape of [Petitioner] 
  talking about buying a kilo [and] how he was going to make it and turn it into 
  crack . . .[On May 18, 1997], one of our stateâ€™s witnesses . . . saw [Petitioner] 
  with approximately a kilogram of cocaine.Â  There are also audiotapes of [Petitionerâ€™s] 
  sisters; again a family business, where they talk about how to make good crack 
  cocaine.

The solicitorâ€™s statements demonstrate the trafficking by conspiracy charge 
  was not based solely on the four instances of distribution for which Petitioner 
  was indicted.Â  Instead, the trafficking charge was based on a pattern of unlawful 
  drug activity over the course of a six-month period.
In sum, neither Matthews , supra, 
  nor any other case, holds Petitionerâ€™s conviction for conspiracy to traffic 
  cocaine and the four counts of distributing cocaine violate double jeopardy.Â  
  Therefore, counsel was not deficient in failing to advise his client on the 
  issue or object to the sentence imposed.
Although, unnecessary for resolution 
  of this case, in the interest of judicial economy, we address the underlying 
  double jeopardy issue.Â  The double jeopardy clauses of the United States and 
  South Carolina Constitutions protect against multiple punishments for the same 
  offense.Â  State v. Nelson, 336 S.C. 186, 519 S.E.2d 786 (1999).Â  A threshold 
  inquiry in this case is whether the same act is involved in different charges.Â  
  Blockburger v. United States, 284 U.S. 299, 52 S.Ct. 180, 76 L.Ed. 306 
  (1932).Â  Trafficking may be accomplished by several means, including conspiracy. 
  [2] Â  Conspiracy is a separate offense from the substantive offense, which 
  is the object of the conspiracy.Â  A defendant may be separately indicted and 
  convicted of both the conspiracy, and the substantive offenses committed in 
  the course of the conspiracy.Â  State v. Gordon, 356 S.C. 143, 149, 588 
  S.E.2d 105, 108 (2003). [3]Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, we hold (1) 
  counsel was not ineffective in failing to advise his client or in failing to 
  object to the double jeopardy issue and (2) there is no underlying double jeopardy 
  violation supporting Petitionerâ€™s claim.
 AFFIRMED.
 TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and
PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

 
  [1] The Court did not apply the test set forth in Blockburger v. United 
    States, 284 U.S. 299, 304, 52 S.Ct. 180, 182, 76 L.Ed. 306, 309 (1932).Â  
    The Blockburger rule is not controlling when legislative intent is 
    clear from the face of the statute or legislative history.Â  Garrett v. 
    United States, 471 U.S. 773, 105 S.Ct. 2407, 85 L.Ed.2d 764 (1985).

 
   [2]  
    S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53- 375(C) states, 
  A person who knowingly sells, manufactures, delivers, 
    purchases, or brings into this State, or who provides financial assistance 
    or otherwise aids, abets, attempts, or conspires to sell, manufacture, deliver, 
    purchase, or bring into this State, or who is knowingly in actual or constructive 
    possession or who knowingly attempts to become in actual or constructive possession 
    of ten grams or more of ice, crank, or crack cocaine . . . is guilty of a 
    felony which is known as â€œtrafficking in ice, crank, or crack cocaineâ€ . . 
    . .

 
   
    [3] Petitionerâ€™s reliance on our holding in Harris v. State, 349 S.C. 
    46, 562 S.E.2d 311 (2002) is misplaced.Â  The issue in Harris was whether 
    conspiracy to traffic was properly classified as a violent offense.Â  South 
    Carolina law provides drug trafficking is a violent offense.Â  We concluded 
    because conspiracy to traffic is one way to traffic drugs under the relevant 
    statutes, conspiracy to traffic cocaine was a violent crime. Â Since the facts 
    in Petitionerâ€™s case do not implicate Harris, it has no bearing on 
    Petitionerâ€™s double jeopardy issue.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Bennie Wicker,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
South Carolina Department of Corrections,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


AFFIRMED

Appeal From Newberry County
James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 25859
Submitted April 21, 2004 - Filed August 
  23, 2004


  
    
      
Lake Eric Summers, of Vinton D. Lide & Associates, of Lexington, for Appellant. 

Bennie Wicker, Jr., of Bennettsville, pro se.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE WALLER:Â  This is a direct 
  appeal from an order of the circuit court which affirmed the decision of the 
  Administrative Law Judge (ALJ).Â  The ALJ held that Respondent, Bennie Wicker, 
  was entitled to be compensated the prevailing wage of $5.25 per hour for the 
  time he was in training for his employment at the South Carolina Department 
  of Corrections (DOC) Division of Prison Industries.Â  Â We affirm.
FACTS
Wicker, while an inmate at Evans Correctional Institute, participated 
  in the Prison Industries Program.Â  During the first 320 hours of his employment, 
  he was paid .25-.75 per hour; he was thereafter paid an hourly wage of $5.25.Â  
  He filed an inmate grievance contending his training wages violated the Prevailing 
  Wage Statute, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-3-430(D) (Supp. 2002).Â  The DOC denied his 
  appeal, and he appealed to the Administrative Law Judge (ALJ).Â  The ALJ reversed 
  the DOCâ€™s decision, finding Wicker was entitled to the prevailing wage during 
  his first 320 hours of employment, and finding no authority for the DOC to deviate 
  from the plain requirement of Â§ 24-3-430.Â  Accordingly, the DOC was ordered 
  to compensate Wicker at a rate of $5.25 per hour for his first 320 hours of 
  work.Â  The circuit court affirmed.Â  
ISSUE

Did the circuit court err in holding Wicker was entitled 
  to a $5.25 per hour training wage?

DISCUSSION
The statutes under which Wicker seeks relief 
  are part of a statutory scheme creating a Prison Industries (PI) program to 
  provide for employment of convicts and utilize their labor for self-maintenance 
  and reimbursement of expenses.Â  SeeÂ  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-3-310 (Supp. 
  2003).Â  In 1995, the General Assembly enacted S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 
  24-3-430, authorizing the DOC to use inmate labor in private industry.Â  
  Section 24-3-430 (D) provides that, â€œ[n]o inmate participating in the program 
  may earn less than the prevailing wage for work of similar nature in the private 
  sector.â€Â  Wicker filed an inmate grievance with the DOC, alleging his training 
  wage of .25-.75 per hour was in violation of the statute.Â  The DOC denied his 
  grievance and he appealed to the ALJ, who reversed.Â  The ALJ found no statutory 
  authority for DOC to pay Wicker less than the prevailing wage;Â  the circuit 
  court affirmed.Â  
The DOC appeals, contending the statutes under 
  which Wicker seeks relief do not entitle him to the prevailing wage, and asserting 
  the ALJ was without subject-matter jurisdiction to hear his appeal.
As recognized in the companion case of Adkins 
  v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Corrections, Op. No. 25860 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed 
  August 23, 2004), we agree with the DOC that section 24-3-430 (D) does not give 
  rise to a private, civil cause of action in Wicker.Â  However, simply because 
  Wicker may not file a civil claim for damages in circuit court does not mean 
  he is without any remedy.Â  There are numerous issues relating to inmates which, 
  although not giving rise to a private, civil cause of action, are nonetheless 
  grievable through DOCâ€™s internal grievance processes.Â  For example, although 
  inmates may not sue for civil damages on matters relating to parole, work release, 
  or work credits, they may enforce such rights via DOC grievance procedures.Â  
  We find no reason such procedures should not apply when an inmate challenges 
  the wages he or she is being paid, particularly where there is a statute mandating 
  payment of the prevailing wage.Â Â  Accordingly, we hold that although Wicker 
  has no claim for civil damages, he properly filed a grievance with the DOC.Â  

The DOC also contends, citing the ALJD's en 
  banc decision in McNeil v. South Carolina Dept. of Corrections, 02-ALJ-04-00336-AP 
  (filed Sept. 5, 2001), that the ALJ was without subject-matter jurisdiction 
  to review its denial of Wickerâ€™s grievance.Â  We disagree.Â  
We find that where, as here, the state has 
  created a statutory right to the payment of a prevailing wage, it cannot thereafter 
  deny that right without affording due process of law.Â  Cf.Â  Piatt 
  v. MacDougall, 773 F.2d 1032, 1036 (9th Cir. 1985) (where state 
  has established, by statute, a right of inmates to compensation for work performed 
  for private parties, it cannot deny that right after they earned the wages, 
  without affording due process of the law); Borror v. White, 377 F. Supp. 
  181 (W.D.Va.1974) (although there was no federal constitutional right to payment, 
  inmate might be entitled to such compensation under state statute).Â Â  
We are not unmindful of our opinion in Sullivan 
  v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Corrections, 355 S.C. 437, 586 S.E.2d 124 (2003), 
  in which we held the ALJ has jurisdiction to review DOC grievance proceedings 
  only if they involve the denial of â€œstate created liberty interests.â€Â  There, 
  we recognized that our opinion in Al-Shabazz v. State, 338 S.C. 354, 
  368, 527 S.E.2d 742, 750 (1999), held that administrative matters typically 
  arise in two ways:Â  (1) when an inmate is disciplined and punishment is imposed 
  and (2) when an inmate believes prison officials have erroneously calculated 
  his sentence, sentence-related credits, or custody status.Â  However, we did 
  not limit Al-Shabazz to these two instances.Â  The Al-Shabazz Court 
  explained that procedural due process is guaranteed when an inmate is deprived 
  of an interest encompassed by the Fourteenth Amendment's protection of liberty 
  and property.Â Â  338 S.C. at 369, 527 S.E.2d at 750.Â  
We find the stateâ€™s statutory mandate that 
  inmates be paid the prevailing wage creates such an interest, which may not 
  be denied without due process.Â  Piatt v. McDougall, supra.Â  Accordingly, 
  in this very limited circumstance, 
  [1]  we hold the DOCâ€™s failure to pay in accordance with the statutes is 
  reviewable by the ALJ.
Finally, we concur with the ALJ and the circuit 
  court that there is simply nothing in the statutory scheme authorizing the DOC 
  to pay Wicker a training wage less than the prevailing wage.Â  Hodges v. Rainey, 
  341 S.C. 79, 85, 533 S.E.2d 578, 581 (2000) (If a statute's language is plain, 
  unambiguous, and conveys a clear meaning, â€œthe rules of statutory interpretation 
  are not needed and the court has no right to impose another meaningâ€).Â  Accordingly, 
  the judgment below is affirmed.Â  
 AFFIRMED.
 TOAL, C.J., and BURNETT, J., concur.Â  PLEICONES, 
  J., dissenting in a separate opinion.Â  MOORE, J., not participating.
JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  As explained more fully in my concurring opinion 
  in Adkins v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Corrections, Op. No. 25860 (S.C. 
  Sup. Ct. filed August 23, 2004), I would hold that respondentâ€™s remedy is found 
  in the South Carolina Payment of Wages Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 41-10-10, et 
  seq. (Supp. 2003).Â  Accordingly, I dissent. 

 
   [1] Â Â  We note that our holding today is extremely 
    limited and is not to be viewed as expanding the jurisdiction of the ALJD 
    in any other circumstance.Â
